Contractor: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA [LINCOLN,NEBRASKA]
Contractor Type: Educational - 1862 Land Grant College, Educational Institution, Nonprofit Organization, State Controlled Institution of Higher Learning
Description of Work: NASA''S PROGRAM FOR ARCTIC REGIONAL CLIMATE ASSESSMENT (PARGA) WAS CONCEIVED IN 1994 AND IMPLEMENTED IN 1995, PRIMARILY TO ESTIMATE THE MASS BALANCE OF THE GREENLAND ICE SHEET(GRLS)THROUGH REPEAT SATELLITE AND AERIAL SURVEYS COMPLEMENTED BY IN-SITU OBSERVATIONS AND MODELING STUDIES. THIS PROPOSAL SEEKS TO DOCUMENT THE SIGNIFICANT OUTCOMES OF PARGA RESEARCH FROM 2001 THROUGH 2015, AND ALSO EVALUATE AND ASSESS THE STATUS OF FIELD PROGRAM OUTCOMES AND DATA RESOURCES THAT LINK THE PAST TO THE FUTURE. A BIBLIOGRAPHY AND DIGITAL COLLECTION (PDF COPIES) OF PARGA-SPECIFIC AND PARGA-RELATED PUBLICATIONS, AND AN ASSESSMENT OF DATA RESOURCES WITH LINKS TO AVAILABLE DATA AND OTHER PRODUCTS, WILL BE CREATED AS THE PRIMARY DELIVERABLES. ANALYSES WILL BE CONDUCTED TO IDENTIFY SIGNIFICANT GAPS IN DATA AVAILABILITY AND ANY PERCEIVED OR ACTUAL RISKS TO THE CONTINUITY OF PARGA TIME-SERIES AND OTHER DATA FOR USE IN ONGOING TARGETED ACTIVITIES, WHICH INCLUDE: (1) IN SITU OBSERVATIONS PROVIDED BY NETWORKS OF AUTOMATED WEATHER STATIONS, (2) CORE COLLECTIONS AND IN SITU MEASUREMENTS OF SNOW/FIRN COMPACTION, (3) OTHER KINDS OF DISTRIBUTED MEASUREMENTS REQUIRED TO REDUCE UNCERTAINTIES AND IMPROVE ESTIMATES OF THE GRLS MASS BALANCE IN ORDER TO CONSTRAIN FUTURE PROJECTIONS OF SEA LEVEL RISE, WHICH ARE USED TO ADVANCE MODEL DEVELOPMENT AND PERFORM VARIOUS SIMULATIONS AND EXPERIMENTS. SITE VISITS TO ACTIVE GRLS RESEARCH HUBS WILL BE USED TO GATHER ADDITIONAL INFORMATION AND IDENTIFY POTENTIAL DATA RESOURCES.

Contractor: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA [LINCOLN,NEBRASKA]
Contractor Type: Educational - 1862 Land Grant College, Corporate Entity Tax Exempt, Educational Institution, Other Not For Profit Organization, State Controlled Institution of Higher Learning
Description of Work: MAPPING LINKAGES BETWEEN GEOPHYSICAL AND BIOLOGICAL DIVERSITY ACROSS SPACE AND TIME IN THE ANDES, AMAZON, AND CHOCO OF PERU, ECUADOR, AND COLOMBIA TROPICAL SOUTH AMERICA IS A KEY REGION ON EARTH, WHOSE RAIN AND CLOUD FORESTS HOST OVER HALF OF ALL TERRESTRIAL PLANT SPECIES. THE FORESTS AND THEIR BIOTA HAVE EVOLVED TOGETHER WITH THE PHYSICAL LANDSCAPE, CLOSELY LINKING PROCESSES IN THE EARTH''S INTERIOR WITH SURFACE LANDSCAPES, CLIMATE, HYDROLOGY, ECOSYSTEMS, AND, ULTIMATELY, BIOTIC DIVERSITY. WE PROPOSE A SET OF WORKSHOPS TO EXAMINE THE INTERCONNECTED RELATIONSHIPS THAT GOVERN ALL ASPECTS OF GEOPHYSICAL DIVERSITY AND PLANT DIVERSITY ACROSS THE DYNAMIC SPATIAL GRADIENTS THAT CHARACTERIZE THE EASTWARD TRANSITION FROM THE HIGH ELEVATION ANDES OF PERU INTO THE LOWLAND AMAZON AND THE WESTWARD TRANSITION FROM THE ANDES OF ECUADOR AND COLOMBIA THROUGH THE CHOCO FOREST TO THE PACIFIC COAST. WE WILL UNDERTAKE GEOPHYSICAL CHARACTERIZATION OF THESE REGIONS AT FINE (METER) SPATIAL SCALES AND AT A RANGE OF TEMPORAL SCALES, FROM HOURS TO MILLIONS OF YEARS. OUR INTERDISCIPLINARY TEAM WILL INCLUDE BIOLOGISTS, GEOLOGISTS, LEADERS IN TROPICAL REMOTE SENSING, CLIMATE DYNAMICISTS, AND MODELERS, WITH EXTENSIVE EXPERIENCE IN THE REGION AND WITH ACCESS TO EXISTING DATA SETS. TOGETHER THIS TEAM WILL EXAMINE HOW PATTERNS OF BIOTIC DIVERSITY OF TROPICAL ECOSYSTEMS, FROM THE HIGH ANDES TO THE EASTERN AND WESTERN LOWLANDS OF PERU, ECUADOR, AND COLOMBIA ARE RELATED TO, AND CONTROLLED BY, BOTH (1) CONTEMPORARY GRADIENTS IN CLIMATE, SOILS, AND LANDFORMS; AND (2) PROCESSES ON EVOLUTIONARY TIMESCALES, INCLUDING TECTONISM, GEOMORPHOLOGY, CLIMATE, AND PHYLOGENETIC HISTORY. OUR PROXIMATE GOAL IS TO ESTABLISH A LINK BETWEEN DISPARATE FIELDS WORKING ON FACTORS CONTROLLING BIODIVERSITY AND ITS ASSESSMENT USING HIGH RESOLUTION ACTIVE AND PASSIVE REMOTE SENSING TECHNIQUES, WITH THE ULTIMATE GOAL OF ASSEMBLING A MECHANISTIC MODEL OF THE PROCESSES THAT COUPLE GEODIVERSITY AND BIODIVERSITY IN BOTH A SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL CONTEXT FOR THESE TWO GLOBALLY UNSURPASSED CENTERS OF BIODIVERSITY. THIS MODEL WILL ENABLE US TO UNDERSTAND AND EVALUATE THE EFFICACY OF CREATING PROTECTED AREAS TO PRESERVE PLANT AND ANIMAL BIODIVERSITY ON THE BASIS OF GEOPHYSICAL DIVERSITY, AS WELL AS ADVANCE THE ABILITY TO ASSESS GEOLOGY AND BIODIVERSITY IN TROPICAL SYSTEMS USING ADVANCED REMOTE SENSING METHODS. OUR WORKSHOPS WILL BRING TOGETHER SEVERAL ACTIVE RESEARCH GROUPS WITH EXTENSIVE RESEARCH EXPERIENCE IN TROPICAL SOUTH AMERICA THAT HAVE NOT COLLABORATED PREVIOUSLY AND THAT ARE MAKING USE OF RECENT ANALYTICAL, TECHNOLOGICAL, AND CONCEPTUAL INNOVATIONS TO ADVANCE FUNDAMENTAL QUESTIONS ABOUT ENVIRONMENTAL PATTERNS AND HISTORY IN THE NEOTROPICS. OUR EFFORTS WILL CAPITALIZE ON AN EXTENSIVE NETWORK OF TREE INVENTORY PLOTS ALONG THE ELEVATION GRADIENT FROM THE HIGHLANDS TO EASTERN LOWLANDS IN PERU, ECUADOR, AND COLOMBIA THAT ENABLE US TO MAP THE CONTEMPORARY ABUNDANCE, DISTRIBUTION, DIVERSITY, AND EARLY RESPONSE TO CLIMATE CHANGE OF FOREST TREES, AND TO PLAN FOR ESTABLISHMENT OF A SIMILAR ALTITUDINAL NETWORK OF TREE PLOTS IN THE CHOCO FOREST. OUR SPATIAL DOMAINS FOCUS ON THREE REGIONS WITH EXCEPTIONAL BIODIVERSITY AND ENDEMISM: (1) PERU, WHICH ALREADY HAS BEEN CHARACTERIZED WITH BOTH ACTIVE AND PASSIVE REMOTE SENSING DATA OF FOREST STRUCTURE AND BIODIVERSITY AND WITH STUDIES OF GEOLOGY, GEOMORPHOLOGY, AND CLIMATE; (2) ECUADOR, WHICH HAS BEEN LITTLE STUDIED FOR ANY OF THESE PARAMETERS; AND (3) COLOMBIA, WITH THE LARGEST AREA OF REMAINING CHOCO FOREST ALONG THE PACIFIC COASTS. THIS NETWORK OF SITES ALSO ALLOWS A STUDY OF LATITUDINAL GRADIENTS OF DIVERSITY FROM THE SOUTHERN PERUVIAN ANDES TO NORTHERN COLOMBIA. SEVERAL TEAM MEMBERS ARE ACTIVE IN REGIONAL CONSERVATION INITIATIVES, THUS FACILITATING TRANSLATION OF WORKSHOP PRODUCTS AND RELATED RESEARCH TO BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION.

Contractor: BOARD OF REGENTS SOUTHWESTERN INDIAN POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE [ALBUQUERQUE,NEW MEXICO]
Contractor Type: Non-Profit Institutions - American Indian Owned, Corporate Entity Tax Exempt, Nonprofit Organization
Description of Work: TO PROMOTE THE ADVANCEMENT OF NATIVE AMERICAN STUDENTS IN INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY (IT) AND SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING AND MATH (STEM) CAREERS SOUTHWESTERN INDIAN POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE (SIPI) PROPOSES TO DEVELOP A YEAR-ROUND ROBOTICS CENTERED IT IMMERSION PROGRAM THAT WILL PROVIDE STUDENTS A STIMULATING LEARNING ENVIRONMENT TO EXPLORE THEIR CURIOSITY AND CREATIVITY IN IT AND STEM FIELDS. TO EXPAND THE IMPACT OF THE PROGRAM, AND THE NUMBER OF STUDENTS REACHED, SIPI WILL PARTNER WITH THREE REGIONAL PUBLIC SCHOOL DISTRICTS WITH PREDOMINANTLY NATIVE AMERICAN STUDENT POPULATION. UTILIZING SIPI S EXPERIENCE IN PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT THE TRIBAL COLLEGES (TCU S), MEMBERS OF THE TCU ENGINEERING PROGRAMS WORKING GROUP, WILL DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT SIMILAR PROGRAMS FROM THEIR CAMPUS TO REACH OUT TO UNDERREPRESENTED STUDENTS IN THEIR LOCAL COMMUNITIES. THE ROBOTIC ELEMENTS OF THIS PROGRAM WILL FOCUS HEAVILY ON PERFORMING REMOTE SCIENCE OPERATIONS, AKIN TO THE MARS EXPLORATION ROVERS, TO PROVIDE AN INTERESTING AND TECHNICALLY RICH IT ENVIRONMENT FOR STUDENTS TO LEARN. STUDENTS WILL GET HANDS ON EXPERIENCE IN OPERATING ROBOTS FROM REMOTE LOCATIONS TO EMPHASIZE THE IMPORTANCE OF COMPUTERS FOR COMPUTATION AND CONTROL, AND COMMUNICATION NETWORKS TO TRANSMIT AND RECEIVE INFORMATION. ADDITIONALLY STUDENTS WILL WORK DIRECTLY WITH ROBOTS TO PROGRAM THEM AND CONFIGURE THEM WITH VARIOUS SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY PAYLOADS. THE CONCEPTS OF SYSTEM INTEGRATION WILL BE LEARNED THROUGH THESE EXPERIENCES TO CREATE A BIG-PICTURE UNDERSTANDING OF HOW IT INFRASTRUCTURE IMPACTS SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY SYSTEMS. THE INTELLECTUAL MERIT OF THIS PROGRAM LIES IN ITS APPLICATION OF A GLOBALLY RECOGNIZED HIGH TECHNOLOGY ACCOMPLISHMENT, THE EXPLORATION OF MARS WITH ROBOTS, AND BRINGING THOSE SAME CONCEPTS TO HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS SO THEY CAN EXPERIENCE FIRSTHAND MANY OF THE TECHNOLOGIES THAT MAKE THESE MISSIONS POSSIBLE. WITHOUT AN ENGAGING CONTEXT TO LEARN IT AND STEM DISCIPLINES, STUDENTS CAN EASILY BE ATTRACTED TO OTHER PROSPECTS AND MAY FIND LITTLE MOTIVATION FOR ENGAGING IN THE HARD WORK OF STUDYING STEM AND IT AT HIGHER LEVELS. FEW IF ANY PROFESSIONALS WORKING IN THE STEM INDUSTRY CHOSE THEIR FIELD BECAUSE IT WAS DIFFICULT. THEY LIKELY CHOSE IT BECAUSE AT SOME POINT THE POSSIBILITY OF CREATING SOMETHING BIGGER THAN THEMSELVES SEEMED POSSIBLE. ONE BROADER IMPACT OF THIS PROPOSAL WILL BE TO INCREASE THE DIVERSITY OF STUDENTS BEING EXPOSED TO THE APPLICATIONS OF IT AND STEM. BY BRINGING CONCEPTS AND TECHNOLOGY THAT ARE COMMONLY VIEWED AS BEING PERFORMED ELSEWHERE BY OTHER PEOPLE DIRECTLY INTO THESE STUDENTS  LIVES THEY WILL REACH NEW LEVELS OF UNDERSTANDING OF IT UNLIKELY TO BE OBTAINED OTHERWISE. THE GOAL OF THIS PROGRAM IS THAT THESE STUDENTS MAY ONE DAY ALSO BE ABLE TO REALIZE DREAMS BY USING TECHNOLOGY TO ACCOMPLISH THINGS WHICH TODAY HAVE YET TO BE IMAGINED.

Description of Work: NASA IS PARTICIPATING WITH THE DOC/NOAA IN A MULTI-SATELLITE PROGRAM TO PROVIDE CONTINUOUS MONITORING OF EARTH AND SPACE ENVIRONMENT PARAMETERS.  THE MONITORED PARAMETERS WILL PROVIDE DATA FOR WEATHER PREDICTION MODELS AND PROVIDE SEVERE WEATHER WARNING DATA.  THE PROGRAM IS TERMED GEOSTATIONARY OPERATIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL SATELLITE (GOES) AND IS ACCOMPLISHED USING TWO NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION (NOAA) GEOSTATIONARY SATELLITES STATIONED AT TWO LONGITUDES OVER THE EQUATOR.  THE GODDARD SPACE FLIGHT CENTER (GSFC) GOES PROJECT OFFICE HAS BEEN GIVEN RESPONSIBILITY FOR PROCURING THE NECESSARY HARDWARE AND SUPPORT SERVICES TO MEET THE MISSION REQUIREMENTS AS SPECIFIED HEREIN.THE SPACECRAFT CONTRACTOR SHALL FURNISH THE NECESSARY PERSONNEL, FACILITIES, SERVICES, AND MATERIALS TO DESIGN, FABRICATE, INTEGRATE, TEST, DELIVER ON-ORBIT TO NASA, AND SUPPORT ON-ORBIT OPERATIONS FOR ALL OF THE GOES N-Q SPACECRAFT DEVELOPED UNDER THIS CONTRACT.  THIS WORK SHALL BE PERFORMED IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE REQUIREMENTS OF THIS DOCUMENT AND ALL ATTACHMENTS TO THE CONTRACT.IN ACCOMPLISHING THE DEVELOPMENT AND DELIVERY OF THE GOES N-Q SPACECRAFT, THE SPACECRAFT CONTRACTOR SHALL PERFORM THE FOLLOWING:1. PROVIDE THE SPACECRAFT BUS AND THE SPACE ENVIRONMENT MONITOR (SEM) INSTRUMENTS FOR EACH OF THE GOES SPACECRAFT.2. RECEIVE THE GFE INSTRUMENTS AND RELATED GROUND SUPPORT EQUIPMENT (GSE), THEN INTEGRATE THEM WITH THE SPACECRAFT BUS AND PERFORM SPACECRAFT LEVEL TESTING.3. PROVIDE ALL REQUIRED SPACECRAFT MECHANICAL AND ELECTRICAL GSE.4. PROVIDE A SPACECRAFT EMULATOR AND INR PERFORMANCE EVALUATION SYSTEM5. DELIVER AND SUPPORT INTEGRATION, VERIFICATION, AND MAINTENANCE OF GROUND SYSTEM HARDWARE AND SOFTWARE.6. DESIGN AND SUPPORT INTEGRATION AND VERIFICATION OF ANY MODIFICATIONS OR REPLACEMENTS TO NOAA GROUND SYSTEM HARDWARE AND SOFTWARE.7. SUPPORT COMBINED SPACECRAFT AND GROUND SYSTEM TESTING, AND GOES END-TO-END TESTING BEFORE LAUNCH.8. PROVIDE ALL SERVICES ASSOCIATED WITH THE LAUNCH VEHICLE PROCUREMENT, LAUNCH BASE PROCESSING FACILITY, LAUNCH BASE COORDINATION AND SAFETY, SPACECRAFT/LAUNCH VEHICLE INTEGRATION AND CHECKOUT, AND LAUNCH.9. PROVIDE ALL SERVICES ASSOCIATED WITH FLIGHT OPERATIONS FROM THE LAUNCH VEHICLE/SPACECRAFT SEPARATION THROUGH SPACECRAFT POSITIONING IN GEOSTATIONARY CHECKOUT ORBIT.10. SUPPORT ALL SERVICES ASSOCIATED WITH THE ON-ORBIT SPACECRAFT CHECKOUT AND SUPPORT ASSOCIATED WITH INSTRUMENT AND INR CHECKOUT.11. PROVIDE SPACECRAFT OPERATOR AND ENGINEERING TRAINING FOR ON-ORBIT OPERATION.12.  PROVIDE ON-ORBIT ENGINEERING SUPPORT FOR THE SPACECRAFT SUPPORT GROUND SYSTEM (SSGS) AND EACH SPACECRAFT.THE SPACECRAFT CONTRACTOR IS REQUIRED TO DELIVER THE GOES N-Q SPACECRAFT FULLY COMPATIBLE AND OPERATIONAL WITH NOAA GROUND SYSTEMS:  THE SATELLITE OPERATIONS CONTROL CENTER (SOCC), SUITLAND, MD; THE WALLOPS COMMAND AND DATA ACQUISITION STATION (WCDAS), WALLOPS, VA; A BACKUP CDAS; AND THE SPACE ENVIRONMENT CENTER (SEC), BOULDER, CO.  CHANGES TO THE EXISTING GROUND SYSTEMS TO ACCOMMODATE UPGRADED OR ADDITIONAL CAPABILITIES ARE PERMITTED AS DEFINED IN SECTION 3.5.  THE CONTRACTOR S DELIVERED SPACECRAFT AND ASSOCIATED EFFORTS SHALL MEET ALL REQUIREMENTS OF THE GOES N-Q PERFORMANCE SPECIFICATION.

Description of Work: IGF::OT::IGF NASA HAS A NEED TO DEVELOP SHADOW MODE ASSESSMENT USING REALISTIC TECHNOLOGIES FOR THE NAS (SMART NAS) CAPABILITY TO ACCELERATE TRANSFORMATION OF THE NAS. TOWARDS THAT END, NASA HAS A NEED FOR IDENTIFYING DETAILED DESIGN ARCHITECTURES TO ENABLE SMART NAS. THIS CAPABILITY WILL ALLOW INTEGRATED, REAL-TIME AND/OR FAST-TIME ASSESSMENT OF GATE-TO-GATE OPERATIONS AND THEIR PERFORMANCE USING REAL-WORLD NAS INPUTS. SMART NAS WOULD ALLOW FOR PLUG-AND-PLAY OF DIFFERENT TECHNOLOGIES TO OPERATE IN COMBINED REAL, VIRTUAL, AND CONSTRUCTIVE MANNERS AS DICTATED BY THE STUDY GOALS. ULTIMATELY, THE SMART NAS CAPABILITY WILL BE DEVELOPED AND IMPLEMENTED BY NASA S AIRSPACE SYSTEMS PROGRAM OF THE AERONAUTICS RESEARCH MISSION DIRECTORATE AND WILL SUPPORT THE GOAL OF ACCELERATING THE TRANSFORMATION OF THE NAS. THE FIRST STEP TOWARDS SUCH DEVELOPMENT IS TO IDENTIFY POSSIBLE ARCHITECTURES, COMPLETE A BENEFITS ASSESSMENT AND COST ESTIMATION. IT IS LIKELY THAT DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF THE SELECTED ARCHITECTURE WILL BE DONE IN-HOUSE, BY CIVIL SERVANTS WITH SUPPORT FROM ON-SITE CONTRACTORS. SCOPE OF WORK EACH OF THE SELECTED CONTRACTORS SHALL PERFORM THE FOLLOWING FUNCTIONAL ELEMENTS:   IDENTIFY AND DEVELOP OPEN ARCHITECTURE ALTERNATIVES FOR A SMART NAS CAPABILITY. THE SIMULATION ARCHITECTURE ITSELF WILL BE OPEN AND THE APPROACH FOR THE SOFTWARE FUNCTIONALITY PORTIONS OF THE ARCHITECTURE WILL ADHERE TO OPEN SOURCE PRINCIPLES.   DOCUMENT AND PRESENT PROPOSED SMART NAS DESIGN ARCHITECTURE CONCEPT STUDIES IN SUFFICIENT DETAIL TO ENABLE EVALUATION BY NASA.   CONDUCT A BENEFITS ASSESSMENT OF THE SMART NAS CAPABILITY.   DEVELOP AN INITIAL COST ESTIMATE FOR CAPABILITY DEVELOPMENT AS WELL AS MAINTENANCE.   IDENTIFY LOGICAL STEPS TO DEVELOP AN OPERATIONAL SMART NAS CAPABILITY.

Description of Work: IGF::OT::IGF  LARGE-SCALE, SWEPT-WING TEST ARTICLES FABRICATION; RESEARCH AND TEST SUPPORT FOR NASA ICING RESEARCH TUNNEL.  UNDER THE AUSPICES OF THE ATMOSPHERIC ENVIRONMENT SAFETY TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT OF NASA S AVIATION SAFETY PROGRAM, RESEARCH IS BEING DIRECTED AT UNDERSTANDING ICE ACCRETION AND AERODYNAMIC EFFECTS FOR LARGE-SCALE SWEPT WINGS.  NASA IS PLANNING TO CONDUCT A SERIES OF ICING TESTS IN THE IRT TO CHARACTERIZE ICE FORMATIONS ON LARGE-SCALE SWEPT WINGS REPRESENTATIVE OF MODERN COMMERCIAL TRANSPORT AIRPLANES.  THE ULTIMATE GOAL OF THE ICING TESTS IS TO GENERATE REPRESENTATIVE ICE ACCRETION ON SWEPT WINGS THAT CAN BE USED FOR SUBSEQUENT AERODYNAMIC EVALUATION IN OTHER EXPERIMENTAL FACILITIES AND FOR VALIDATION OF ICE-ACCRETION PREDICTION CODES.

Contractor Type: Other Than Small Business - Corporate Entity Not Tax Exempt, For Profit Organization, Manufacturer Of Goods
Description of Work: IGF::OT::IGF  ULTR-LIGHT HIGHLY EFFICIENT MW-CLASS CRYOGENICALLY-COOLED INVERTER FOR FUTURE ALL ELECTRIC AIRCRAFT APPLICATIONS. BOEING, AS THE PRIME CONTRACTOR SHALL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR OVERALL PROJECT MANAGEMENT, THERMAL MANAGEMENT AND MECHANICAL SYSTEM DESIGN, INVERTER SYSTEM DESIGN AND INTEGRATION. UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE-KNOXVILLE (UTK) WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR TOPOLOGY EVALUATION, SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICE SELECTION, CHARACTERIZATION AND GATE DRIVE, EMI FILTER, AND INVERTER PROTOTYPING. BOTH TEAMS WILL WORK TOGETHER ON SYSTEM INTEGRATION AND TESTING.THE OVERALL OBJECTIVE IS TO DEVELOP INVERTER TECHNOLOGIES THAT WILL ENABLE A CRYOGENICALLY COOLED INVERTER AT 1-MW POWER LEVEL TO ACHIEVE OR EVEN EXCEED THE EFFICIENCY TARGET OF 99.3% AT 500 KW AND SPECIFIC-POWER TARGET OF 26 KW/KG. THE INVERTER TECHNOLOGIES SHOULD BE SCALABLE, RELIABLE, AND DEMONSTRATE A TECHNICAL READINESS LEVEL OF AT LEAST 4. THE INVERTER WILL BE DESIGNED TO DELIVER THE MW-LEVEL POWER AT REQUIRED INPUT DC VOLTAGE LEVEL OF 1000 V AND AC OUTPUT FREQUENCY RANGE OF 200-3000 HZ, WHILE MEETING THE PQ AND EMI REQUIREMENTS. THE PROTOTYPES OF 200 KW AND 1 MW WITH SUFFICIENT TECHNOLOGY AND FUNCTIONALITY MATURITY WILL BE BUILT AND TESTED TO DEMONSTRATE THE POSSIBILITY OF SUCH AN INVERTER FOR FUTURE AIRCRAFT PROPULSION.

Description of Work: IGF::OT::IGF  CONTRACT NNC15BA11B RESEARCH AND TECHNOLOGIES FOR AEROSPACE PROPULSION SYSTEMS 2 - RTAPS 2 INCLUDES TECHNOLOGY AREA(2), THREE(3), AND FOUR(4). SUCCESSFUL TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPMENT IN SPACE PROPULSION (TECHNOLOGY AREA 2) WILL ENABLE MISSIONS WITH HIGHER PERFORMANCE, REDUCED COST, IMPROVED OPERABILITY/RELIABILITY, AND IMPROVED SAFETY. MISSION APPLICATIONS WILL SPAN THE ENTIRE CONTINUUM WHERE SPACE PROPULSION IS TYPICALLY USED FROM ASCENT THROUGH IN-SPACE OPERATIONS INCLUDING RETURN PHASES.  BOEING RESEARCH IN THE AREA OF SPACE COMMUNICATION WILL ENABLE FUTURE NASA SPACE MISSIONS BY DEVELOPING TECHNOLOGIES THAT ACHIEVE IMPROVEMENTS IN COMMUNICATION DATA RATES AND NAVIGATION PRECISION, WHICH ARE NEEDED FOR FUTURE MISSIONS AND WILL ENABLE ENTIRELY NEW MISSION CONCEPTS. (TECHNOLOGY AREA 4). UNDER THE AERONAUTICS RESEARCH MISSION DIRECTORATE, BOEING WILL CONDUCT FUNDAMENTAL, CUT-TING-EDGE RESEARCH INTO NEW AIRCRAFT TECHNOLOGIES AS WELL AS INTEGRATION OF NEW OPERATIONS CON-CEPTS AND TECHNOLOGIES INTO THE NEXT GENERATION AIR TRANSPORTATION SYSTEM.  COMMUNICATIONS, NAVIGATION, SURVEILLANCE AND INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPMENT WILL SUPPORT THE GOALS TO ENABLE INCREASING AIRSPACE SYSTEM CAPACITY AND EFFICIENCY, IMPROVING AVIATION SYSTEM SAFETY, AND ADVANCING THE INTEGRATION OF UNMANNED AIRCRAFT INTO THE NATIONAL AIRSPACE SYSTEM (TECHNOLOGY AREA 3). Contractor Type: Other Than Small Business - Corporate Entity Not Tax Exempt, For Profit Organization, Manufacturer Of Goods
Description of Work: IGF::OT::IGF  NOISE REDUCTION TECHNOLOGIES FOR ADVANCED SUBSONIC COMMERCIAL AIRCRAFT.  THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS RESEARCH IS TO IDENTIFY LOW-NOISE LANDING GEAR DESIGN(S) THAT ARE SUITABLE FOR DEPLOYMENT ON REAL AIRCRAFT WITH ACCEPTABLE IMPACT ON WEIGHT, STRUCTURE, AND STOWABILITY. THE FINAL LOW NOISE CONFIGURATION SHALL TARGET A D-WEIGHTED OVERALL SOUND PRESSURE LEVEL (OASPL) NOISE REDUCTION OF 5 DB FOR AN OBSERVER DIRECTLY BELOW THE FULL SCALE MAIN LANDING GEAR, WITH MINIMUM AND STRETCH TARGET GOALS OF 3 AND 8 DB, RESPECTIVELY. THIS WILL REQUIRE A HOLISTIC APPROACH INVOLVING THE EVALUATION OF THE ENTIRE LANDING GEAR SYSTEM. AS SUCH, THE GEAR, THE WHEEL WELL DETAILS, AND THE DOORS SHALL BE INVESTIGATED IN TASK I AND THE ADDITIONAL EFFECTS OF INTERACTION WITH THE HIGH-LIFT SYSTEMS AND THE CURVED LOWER FUSELAGE SURFACE WILL BE INCORPORATED IN TASK 2.THE FIRST TASK SHALL BUILD UPON THE KNOWLEDGE OF ISOLATED MAIN LANDING GEAR NOISE AND RECENT DEVELOPMENTS ON LANDING GEAR NOISE REDUCTION CONDUCTED AT NASA. BOTH PASSIVE AND ACTIVE NOISE REDUCTION CONCEPTS SHALL BE EVALUATED USING A SYNERGISTIC COMBINATION OF TIME ACCURATE NUMERICAL SIMULATIONS AND SUFFICIENTLY RELIABLE WIND TUNNEL MEASUREMENTS, THROUGH WHICH A SUBSET OF MOST SUITABLE DESIGNS FOR LANDING GEAR NOISE REDUCTION CONCEPTS SHALL BE IDENTIFIED ON THE BASIS OF THEIR FEASIBILITY OF IMPLEMENTATION, AERODYNAMICS, AND NOISE REDUCTION.

Contractor Type: Other Than Small Business - Corporate Entity Not Tax Exempt, For Profit Organization, Manufacturer Of Goods
Description of Work: IGF::OT::IGF  THE OBJECTIVE OF THE FIRST PHASE OF THIS RESEARCH IS TO DEVELOP A DESIGN AND ASSESS THE FEASIBILITY OF A LINER THAT WILL MEET THE GOALS STATED IN THE NRA: BROADBAND ACOUSTIC PERFORMANCE THAT MEETS OR EXCEEDS CONVENTIONAL STATIC MULTI-DEGREE OF FREEDOM (MDOF) LINERS. THE FREQUENCY RANGE FOR IMPROVED ACOUSTIC PERFORMANCE INCLUDES 1.0 TO 6.0 KHZ FOR A FULL-SCALE TURBOFAN ENGINE (FAN DIAMETER APPROXIMATELY 6-9 FT.) DRAG REDUCTION EQUIVALENT TO 80% OF THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN CONVENTIONAL STATIC MDOF AND HARD WALL VALUESAN IMPORTANT ELEMENT OF THIS WORK WILL BE THE PROPER ASSESSMENT OF THE ADAPTIVE FACESHEET PROPERTIES WITH THE TUNABLE RESONATOR COMPONENT. THE SMA FACESHEET WILL HAVE AT MINIMUM TWO CONDITIONS, ONE THAT REPLICATES THE PERCENTAGE OPEN AREA COMPARABLE TO THAT OF A CONVENTIONAL LINER, AND A SECOND WHERE THE FACESHEET IS SMOOTH LIKE A HARD WALL SEGMENT OF A NACELLE. INTERMEDIATE POSITIONS WILL ALSO BE CONSIDERED TO OPTIMIZE THE OVERALL ACOUSTIC PERFORMANCE OF THE LINER AT ALL FREQUENCIES.THE OBJECTIVES OF THE SECOND PHASE WILL BE TO BUILD AND TEST THE FULL LINER CONCEPT. DURING DEVELOPMENT, THE ACOUSTIC PROPERTIES OF THE LINER WILL BE VERIFIED BY IMPEDANCE TUBE TESTING AT THE FACILITIES OF FLORIDA STATE UNIVERSITY. THE DESIGN OF THE FACESHEET CONFIGURATION WILL BE GUIDED BY RECENT FINDINGS BY BOEING AND NASA ON FACESHEET DRAG AND VERIFIED IN THE FSU FACILITIES. BOEING WILL DELIVER LINER HARDWARE TO NASA LANGLEY THAT IS SUITABLE FOR TESTING IN THE NASA GRAZING FLOW IMPEDANCE TUBE FACILITY (GFIT).QUALITY ASSURANCE IN ALL PHASES OF THE PROJECT WILL BE MADE THROUGH CONSULTATION AND INDEPENDENT REVIEW OF PLANS AND PROGRESS BY TECHNICAL EXPERTS AT BOEING.

Description of Work: IGF::OT::IGF  TASK ORDER NNC16JA04T, TECHNICAL AREA 4, FOR CONTRACT NNC15BA11B RESEARCH AND TECHNOLOGIES FOR AEROSPACE PROPULSION SYSTEMS 2 - RTAPS 2 INCLUDES TECHNOLOGY AREA(2), THREE(3), AND FOUR(4). DEVELOP, DEMONSTRATE, AND VERIFY ADVANCED PROPULSION AND COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEM TECHNOLOGIES AS PART OF NASA''S ONGOING, LONG-TERM AEROSPACE RESEARCH PROGRAMS. SUCCESSFUL TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPMENT IN SPACE PROPULSION (TECHNOLOGY AREA 2) WILL ENABLE MISSIONS WITH HIGHER PERFORMANCE, REDUCED COST, IMPROVED OPERABILITY/RELIABILITY, AND IMPROVED SAFETY. MISSION APPLICATIONS WILL SPAN THE ENTIRE CONTINUUM WHERE SPACE PROPULSION IS TYPICALLY USED FROM ASCENT THROUGH IN-SPACE OPERATIONS INCLUDING RETURN PHASES. BOEING RESEARCH IN THE AREA OF SPACE COMMUNICATION WILL ENABLE FUTURE NASA SPACE MISSIONS BY DEVELOPING TECHNOLOGIES THAT ACHIEVE IMPROVEMENTS IN COMMUNICATION DATA RATES AND NAVIGATION PRECISION, WHICH ARE NEEDED FOR FUTURE MISSIONS AND WILL ENABLE ENTIRELY NEW MISSION CONCEPTS. (TECHNOLOGY AREA 4). UNDER THE AERONAUTICS RESEARCH MISSION DIRECTORATE, BOEING WILL CONDUCT FUNDAMENTAL, CUT-TING-EDGE RESEARCH INTO NEW AIRCRAFT TECHNOLOGIES AS WELL AS INTEGRATION OF NEW OPERATIONS CON-CEPTS AND TECHNOLOGIES INTO THE NEXT GENERATION AIR TRANSPORTATION SYSTEM.  COMMUNICATIONS, NAVIGATION, SURVEILLANCE AND INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPMENT WILL SUPPORT THE GOALS TO ENABLE INCREASING AIRSPACE SYSTEM CAPACITY AND EFFICIENCY, IMPROVING AVIATION SYSTEM SAFETY, AND ADVANCING THE INTEGRATION OF UNMANNED AIRCRAFT INTO THE NATIONAL AIRSPACE SYSTEM (TECHNOLOGY AREA 3).

Description of Work: IGF::OT::IGF  TASK ORDER FOR USER MISSION ANTENNA STUDY

Contractor Type: Other Than Small Business - Corporate Entity Not Tax Exempt, For Profit Organization, Manufacturer Of Goods
Description of Work: IGF::OT::IGFNASA''S SPACE COMMUNICATIONS AND NAVIGATION (SCAN) PROGRAM IS INVESTIGATING POTENTIAL OPTIONS FOR PROVIDING COMMUNICATIONS SERVICES SIMULTANEOUSLY TO MULTIPLE USER MISSIONS IN LOW EARTH ORBIT (LEO) VIA ADVANCED MULTIPLE BEAM AND MULTIPLE ACCESS (MB/MA) TECHNIQUES. THESE ARE BEING EXPLORED FOR POTENTIAL USE ON FUTURE NEAR-EARTH COMMUNICATIONS RELAY SATELLITES IN GEOSYNCHRONOUS EARTH ORBIT (GEO).  OPTIONS OF INTEREST IN THIS STUDY ARE ADVANCED ALTERNATIVES TO SERVICE PROVISION TECHNIQUES USED ON THE CURRENT TRACKING AND DATA RELAY SATELLITES (TDRS). THOSE ARE S-BAND MULTIPLE ACCESS (SMA) VIA PHASED ARRAY WITH GROUND-BASED BEAM-FORMING, AND S-BAND&KA-BAND SINGLE ACCESS (SSA&KASA) VIA BY MECHANICALLY STEERED PARABOLIC DISHES.  KU-BAND SINGLE ACCESS SERVICE IS EXPECTED TO END WITH THE CURRENT FLEET OF TDRSS.  THE PURPOSE OF THIS STUDY IS TO EVALUATE THE POTENTIAL OF ELECTRONICALLY STEERED OR SWITCHED MULTIPLE BEAM ANTENNA SYSTEMS TO PROVIDE ADVANCED MULTIPLE ACCESS SERVICES IN KA-BAND.MB/MA ANTENNAS UNDER CONSIDERATION IN THIS STUDY ARE: (1) DIRECT PHASED ARRAYS (POSSIBLY SEPARATE TRANSMIT AND RECEIVE ARRAYS) PROVIDING MULTIPLE SIMULTANEOUS ELECTRONICALLY-STEERED BEAMS; (2) PHASED ARRAY-FED REFLECTORS THAT USE A REFLECTOR TO INCREASE THE ARRAY''S GAIN WHILE MAINTAINING THE REQUIRED FIELD OF REGARD (FOR) (NOTE THAT THIS IS DIFFERENT FROM A CONFOCAL-FED PHASED ARRAY CONCEPT); AND (3) AND MULTIPLE SIMULTANEOUS SPOT BEAMS WHERE SPOT BEAMS ARE ELECTRONICALLY SWITCHED TO TRACK USER MISSIONS AND THE USER MISSION HAND-OFFS ARE HANDLED ONBOARD THE RELAY.  IN ALL THREE CASES, BEAM-FORMING, BEAM STEERING OR SWITCHING, AND CONTROLLING IS PERFORMED ONBOARD THE RELAY SATELLITE.  IT IS IMPORTANT TO NOTE THAT HAND-OFFS OF USER MISSIONS BETWEEN SPOT BEAMS AND THE NEED FOR DIRECTIONAL BEAMS ON USER MISSION SPACECRAFT HAVE BEEN ASSUMED TO IMPOSE ADDITIONAL, UNWANTED USER BURDEN BY SOME IN THE SCAN PROGRAM.  THE KA-BAND SPACE-TO-SPACE SPECTRUM ALLOCATION FOR SCIENCE USE HAS MORE THAN SUFFICIENT BANDWIDTH (1.5 GHZ) TO ACCOMMODATE ANY PROJECTED AGGREGATE NASA MISSION USE.  CANDIDATE MB/MA TECHNIQUES IDENTIFIED BY THE OFFEROR SHOULD CONSIDER PARTITIONING OR CHANNELIZING THE AVAILABLE SPECTRUM INTO A LOW-DATA RATE MULTI-USER SERVICE SIMILAR TO THE CURRENT SMA SPREAD SPECTRUM FUNCTIONALITY, AND A FLEXIBLE SPECTRUM CHANNELIZATION AND MULTIPLE ACCESS TECHNIQUE FOR HIGHER DATA RATE USERS THAT COULD POTENTIALLY SERVE MULTIPLE HIGH DATA-RATE USERS AT ONCE DEPENDING ON DATA NEEDS.A KEY CONCERN FOR THIS STUDY IS BALANCING BETWEEN THE COMMUNICATIONS LINK BURDEN BETWEEN THE RELAY SATELLITE AND THE USER MISSIONS.  MANY OF THE CURRENT TDRS USERS ACCESS THE SSA SERVICE VIA OMNI-DIRECTIONAL ANTENNAS TO PROVIDE LOW DATA-RATE (1-8 KBPS) TRACKING, TELEMETRY AND CONTROL (TT&C) FUNCTIONALITY.  FUTURE USERS WITH SIMILAR NEEDS WOULD REQUIRE A HIGHER RELAY G/T THAN TDRS SMA FOR THE FUTURE RELAY MB/MA PAYLOAD TO PROVIDE THESE SAME SERVICES VIA A KA-BAND OMNI ANTENNA ON THE USER MISSION SPACECRAFT. OR, THE USER WOULD NEED TO INCORPORATE A HIGHER GAIN, STEERABLE ANTENNA OF SOME FORM. ALTERNATIVES FOR KA-BAND USER MISSION ANTENNAS IS THE TOPIC OF A SEPARATE RTAPS2 TASK ORDER STUDY CONTRACT.FINALLY, THE 2ND AND 3RD GENERATION TDRS KASA SYSTEMS HAVE A RELATIVELY HIGH KA-BAND G/T, AND HAVE SET EXPECTATIONS FOR FUTURE RELAY SYSTEMS.  ACHIEVING THE DESIRED G/T MAY BE PROHIBITIVELY DIFFICULT FOR SOME OF THE FUTURE CANDIDATE SOLUTIONS. THEREFORE THIS STUDY SHOULD ALSO INVESTIGATE LOWER PERFORMANCE MB/MA SOLUTIONS AS OPTIONS.  LOWER RECEIVER G/T ON THE RELAY WITH INCREASED USER BURDEN FOR EIRP IS ONE POSSIBILITY.

Description of Work: IGF::OT::IGF  UNDER THE AUSPICES OF THE ADVANCED AIR TRANSPORT TECHNOLOGY PROJECT OF THE ADVANCED AIR VEHICLES PROGRAM RESEARCH IS BEING DIRECTED AT UNDERSTANDING ICE ACCRETION AND AERODYNAMIC EFFECTS FOR LARGE SCALE SWEPT WINGS. NASA HAS PARTNERED WITH FAA AND ONERA TO SUPPORT THIS EFFORT. A SERIES OF ICING TESTS IN THE ICING RESEARCH TUNNEL IRT HAVE BEEN CONDUCTED TO CHARACTERIZE ICE FORMATIONS ON LARGE SCALE SWEPT WINGS REPRESENTATIVE OF MODERN COMMERCIAL TRANSPORT AIRPLANES. THE RESULT IS A LARGE DATABASE OF ICE ACCRETION GEOMETRY THAT CAN BE USED FOR SUBSEQUENT AERODYNAMIC EVALUATION IN OTHER EXPERIMENTAL FACILITIES AND FOR VALIDATION OF ICE ACCRETION PREDICTION CODES.

Contractor Type: Other Than Small Business - Corporate Entity Not Tax Exempt, For Profit Organization, Manufacturer Of Goods
Award Type: Definitive Contract, Cost Plus Fixed Fee
Description of Work: This procurement is a result of a NASA Research Announcement (NRA), NNH07ZEA001N-IRAC1 that was issued on June 8, 2007 to solicit proposals in support of NASA's Aeronautics Research Mission Directorate (ARMD).  One of the proposals, Dynamic Flight Envelope Assessment and Prediction" (proposal number 07-IRAC-07-0034) submitted by The Boeing Company (DBA Boeing), was selected to support the Aviation Safety Program, and in particular the Integrated Resilient Aircraft Control (IRAC) Project.  The primary goal of the Dynamic Flight Envelope Assessment and Prediction program is to provide NASA with flight safety enhancement through a process to identify fault damage anomalies in air-vehicle structure, predict an allowable flight maneuver loads envelope for the damaged vehicle, and measure changes in structure dynamics mode shapes due to the damage. The system will also provide adaptive control to maintain the aircraft within the structure limits and suppress any adverse structure dynamic mode interaction with the flight control system. The program's primary focus is on Control-Centric Modeling, combining rigid body models with dynamic flexible structure and loads models to provide the basis for on-line adaptive control of the structure properties of the aircraft. Program products will be algorithms and processes that can provide control of structures properties for tactical and transport aircraft. This program addresses system anomalies caused by battle damage to military aircraft and structure failures to civil aircraft caused by incidents such as fatigue, corrosion, mid-air collisions, or improper procedures. The program builds on the NASA Intelligent Flight Control System technology, already demonstrated on a research F-15 for adaptive control of the aerodynamic capability of a damaged aircraft. The significance of this program is to add a capability by using adaptive control to prevent excessive structure loads or dynamic interaction, thereby increasing the safety and survivability of air and space vehicles. The program will assist NASA on meeting the objectives of the NASA Aviation Safety Program. This program addresses IRAC Topic 1.3, Dynamic Flight Envelope Assessment and Prediction.   This acquisition will result in a three year Cost-plus-Fixed-Fee contract to be conducted by The Boeing Company, Phantom Works division, St. Louis, MO for a total amount of $1,127,367.  "

Description of Work: IGF::OT::IGF THIS IS FOR CONDUCTING LABORATORY STUDIES OF THE MECHANICAL AND THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES OF ICY REGOLITH LIKELY TO BE FOUND IN THE PERMANENTLY SHADOWED LUNAR POLAR CRATERS. THE STRENGTH OF ICY MATERIALS MUST BE DETERMINED TO ENABLE THE DESIGN OF AN EFFECTIVE DRILL AND SAMPLING SYSTEM. THE THERMAL PROPERTIES OF ICY MATERIALS MUST ALSO BE KNOWN TO ENSURE THAT EVAPORATIVE LOSS OF ICE WOULD NOT OCCUR DURING DRILLING. THE CONTRACTOR PLANS TO CHARACTERIZE THE MECHANICAL AND THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES OF ICY REGOLITH MARE AND HIGHLAND LUNAR SIMULANTS WITH VARYING DEGREES OF WATER CONTENT, IN A VACUUM CHAMBER AT TEMPERATURES SIMILAR TO TEMPERATURES FOUND IN PERMANENTLY SHADOWED CRATERS. ONE OF THE GOALS OF THE STUDY IS TO DETERMINE AN UNCONFINED COMPRESSIVE STRENGTH (UCS) OF MIXTURES OF LUNAR SOIL SIMULANT AND WATER AND OTHER ICES AT LOW TEMPERATURE AS A FUNCTION OF ICE CONTENT. THE UCS IS THE PRIMARY PROPERTY OF THE MATERIAL THAT AFFECTS DRILLING AND EXCAVATION ENERGY, REQUIRED POWER, AND WEIGHT-ON-BIT. UNDERSTANDING THE THERMOPHYSICAL PROPERTIES OF ICY SOIL AT CRYOGENIC TEMPERATURES IS IMPORTANT FROM A SCIENTIFIC STANDPOINT AND ALSO IN DETERMINING WHETHER A PROPOSED EXCAVATION OPERATION WOULD THERMALLY ALTER THE DEPOSIT. ONE OF THE GOALS OF THE STUDY IS TO DETERMINE AN UNCONFINED COMPRESSIVE STRENGTH (UCS) OF MIXTURES OF LUNAR SOIL SIMULANT AND WATER AND OTHER ICES AT LOW TEMPERATURE AS A FUNCTION OF ICE CONTENT.  THE UCS IS THE PRIMARY PROPERTY OF THE MATERIAL THAT AFFECTS DRILLING AND EXCAVATION ENERGY, REQUIRED POWER, AND WEIGHT-ON-BIT.  UNDERSTANDING THE THERMOPHYSICAL PROPERTIES OF ICY SOIL AT CRYOGENIC TEMPERATURES IS IMPORTANT FROM A SCIENTIFIC STANDPOINT AND ALSO IN DETERMINING WHETHER A PROPOSED EXCAVATION OPERATION WOULD THERMALLY ALTER THE DEPOSIT. ONE OF THE GOALS OF THE STUDY IS TO DETERMINE AN UNCONFINED COMPRESSIVE STRENGTH (UCS) OF MIXTURES OF LUNAR SOIL SIMULANT AND WATER AND OTHER ICES AT LOW TEMPERATURE AS A FUNCTION OF ICE CONTENT. UCS IS THE PRIMARY PROPERTY OF THE MATERIAL THAT AFFECTS DRILLING AND EXCAVATION ENERGY, REQUIRED POWER, AND WEIGHT-ON-BIT.  UNDERSTANDING THE THERMOPHYSICAL PROPERTIES OF ICY SOIL AT CRYOGENIC TEMPERATURES IS IMPORTANT FROM A SCIENTIFIC STANDPOINT AND ALSO IN DETERMINING WHETHER A PROPOSED EXCAVATION OPERATION WOULD THERMALLY ALTER THE DEPOSIT. THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES OF INTEREST INCLUDE THERMAL CONDUCTIVITY, SPECIFIC HEAT, AND THE LATENT HEAT OF FUSION OF SOIL-ICE MIXTURES OVER THE RANGE OF TEMPERATURES EXPECTED IN THE PERMANENTLY SHADOWED CRATERS.  THERMAL PROPERTIES OF WATER ICE DEPEND STRONGLY ON TEMPERATURE; HOWEVER, THE PROPERTIES OF SOIL-ICE MIXTURES AT CRYOGENIC TEMPERATURES IN VACUUM HAVE NOT BEEN DETERMINED.  HERE THE CONTRACTOR PROPOSES TO INVESTIGATE THE THERMAL PROPERTIES OF SOIL-ICE MIXTURES RANGING FROM A FEW PERCENT TO 12 PERCENT (SATURATED) WATER BY WEIGHT.

Contractor Type: Other Than Small Business - Corporate Entity Not Tax Exempt, For Profit Organization, Manufacturer Of Goods
Description of Work: IGF::OT::IGF BAA - NEXT SPACE TECHNOLOGIES FOR EXPLORATION PARTNERSHIPS (NEXTSTEP) PROPOSAL - HABITATION.  NASA HAS INCREASINGLY EMBRACED PUBLIC-PRIVATE PARTNERSHIPS FOR ACHIEVING ITS STRATEGIC GOALS AND OBJECTIVES FOR EXPANDING THE FRONTIERS OF KNOWLEDGE, CAPABILITY, AND OPPORTUNITIES IN SPACE. THE NEXT STEP FOR HUMAN SPACEFLIGHT IS THE DEVELOPMENT OF DEEP SPACE EXPLORATION CAPABILITIES TO SUPPORT MORE EXTENSIVE MISSIONS IN THE PROVING GROUND AROUND AND BEYOND CISLUNAR SPACE. AN IMPORTANT PART OF NASAS STRATEGY IS TO STIMULATE THE COMMERCIAL SPACE INDUSTRY WHILE LEVERAGING THOSE SAME COMMERCIAL CAPABILITIES THROUGH FUTURE CONTRACTS AND PUBLIC-PRIVATE PARTNERSHIPS TO DELIVER MISSION CAPABILITIES.  NASAS ACTIVITIES IN ENABLING THE PIONEERING OF SPACE ARE BEING DRIVEN BY A SET OF GUIDING PRINCIPLES:    IMPLEMENTABLE IN THE NEAR-TERM WITH THE BUYING POWER OF CURRENT BUDGETS AND IN THE LONGER TERM WITH BUDGETS COMMENSURATE WITH ECONOMIC GROWTH;    EXPLORATION ENABLES SCIENCE AND SCIENCE ENABLES EXPLORATION    APPLICATION OF HIGH TECHNOLOGY READINESS LEVEL (TRL) TECHNOLOGIES FOR NEAR TERM MISSIONS, WHILE FOCUSING SUSTAINED INVESTMENTS ON TECHNOLOGIES AND CAPABILITIES TO ADDRESS CHALLENGES OF FUTURE MISSIONS;    NEAR-TERM MISSION OPPORTUNITIES WITH A DEFINED CADENCE OF COMPELLING AND INTEGRATED HUMAN AND ROBOTIC MISSIONS PROVIDING FOR AN INCREMENTAL BUILDUP OF CAPABILITIES FOR MORE COMPLEX MISSIONS OVER TIME;    OPPORTUNITIES FOR U.S. COMMERCIAL BUSINESS TO FURTHER ENHANCE THE EXPERIENCE AND BUSINESS BASE    MULTI-USE, EVOLVABLE SPACE INFRASTRUCTURE, MINIMIZING UNIQUE MAJOR DEVELOPMENTS;    SUBSTANTIAL INTERNATIONAL AND COMMERCIAL PARTICIPATION, LEVERAGING CURRENT INTERNATIONAL SPACE STATION AND OTHER PARTNERSHIPS. THE CONTRACTOR SHALL DEVELOP A SIMPLE, LOW COST EXPLORATION AUGMENTATION MODULE (EAM) THAT IS AFFORDABLE EARLY ON, THAT ALLOWS VARIOUS TECHNOLOGIES TO BE TESTED OVER TIME, AND THAT IS CAPABLE OF EVOLVING INTO A LONG-DURATION CREW SUPPORT SYSTEM FOR CISLUNAR AND MARS EXPLORATION.

Description of Work: IGF::OT::IGFTHE COMMERCIAL CREW PROGRAM (CCP) COMMERCIAL CREW TRANSPORTATION CAPABILITY (CCTCAP) CONTRACT WILL PROVIDE COMPLETION OF THE DESIGN, DEVELOPMENT, TEST, EVALUATION, AND CERTIFICATION OF AN INTEGRATED CREW TRANSPORTATION SYSTEM (CTS) CAPABLE OF TRANSPORTING NASA CREW TO AND FROM THE ISS, IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE DESIGN REFERENCE MISSIONS AND NASA S CERTIFICATION STANDARDS AND REQUIREMENTS.  CERTIFICATION OF THE CTS WILL BE DETERMINED BY NASA.  NASA PLANS TO ISSUE TASK ORDERS FOR POST CERTIFICATION MISSIONS (PCM) TO AND FROM ISS THAT INCLUDE GROUND, LAUNCH, LIFEBOAT, ON-ORBIT, RETURN AND RECOVERY OPERATIONS. THE MINIMUM QUANTITY OF MISSIONS TO BE ORDERED IS TWO (2) AND THE MAXIMUM POTENTIAL QUANTITY OF MISSIONS WHICH MAY BE ORDERED IS SIX (6).  IN ADDITION, NASA MAY ISSUE TASK ORDERS FOR SPECIAL STUDIES USED FOR RISK REDUCTION AND OTHER PURPOSES RELATED TO THE CTS. SUBCLINS 001A AND 001B, IDENTIFIED IN TABLE B.3,DDTE/CERTIFICATION SUBCLINS, ARE DELIVERY MILESTONES THAT REPRESENT COMPLETION OF REQUIREDWORK NECESSARY TO ACHIEVE NASA CERTIFICATION. DELIVERY PAYMENT FOR THE ISS DESIGNCERTIFICATION REVIEW (DCR) FOR THE CREWED FLIGHT TO THE ISS INCLUDES ALL WORK UNDER THIS CLIN THATOCCURS FROM THE CONTRACT EFFECTIVE DATE THROUGH THE ISS DCR COMPLETION. THE DELIVERY PAYMENTFOR THE CERTIFICATION REVIEW (CR) WILL INCLUDE ALL WORK THAT OCCURS FROMTHE ISS DCR DELIVERY DATETHROUGH THE END OF THE DDTE/CERTIFICATION CLIN 001.IN ACCORDANCE WITH CLAUSE C.1, SPECIFICATION/STATEMENT OF WORK, THE TASK ORDERING PROCEDURES ANDOTHER TERMS AND CONDITIONS IN THE CONTRACT, THE CONTRACTING OFFICER MAY ISSUE POST CERTIFICATIONMISSION (PCM) TASK ORDERS. THE PER MISSION PRICES ARE FOR A SINGLE ORDER AT THE PRICESTATED PER THE CALENDAR YEAR (CY) BASED ON THE NUMBER OF MISSIONS ORDERED. CTS FULL MISSIONCAPABILITY PRICES SHALL BE BASED ON (1) FULFILLMENT OF THE DESIGN REFERENCE MISSION TO THE ISS FOUNDIN CCT-DRM-1110, CREW TRANSPORTATION SYSTEM DESIGN REFERENCE MISSIONS, ATTACHMENT J-03,CONTRACT PERFORMANCE WORK STATEMENT, AND OTHER TERMS AND CONDITIONS IN THE CONTRACT AND (2) ALLINHERENT CTS CAPABILITIES THAT ARE WITHIN THE PROPOSED MISSION PRICES.IN ACCORDANCE WITH ATTACHMENT J-03, CONTRACT PERFORMANCE WORK STATEMENT, THE TASK ORDERINGPROCEDURES AND OTHER TERMS AND CONDITIONS IN THE CONTRACT, THE CONTRACTOR SHALL PERFORM SPECIALSTUDIES, TEST AND ANALYSES, AS INITIATED BY WRITTEN DIRECTION FROM THE CONTRACTING OFFICER

Description of Work: NRA: NNH07ZEA001N-HYP1.  Proposal: 07-HYP-0087. Entitled: Development of System-Level Optimization with Uncertainty.  BACKGROUND:  The goal of this project is to develop a capability for optimization with uncertainty, demonstrate this capability on a hypersonic vehicle test case using system-level analysis, and to use the demonstration to evaluate certain design process issues.  This study supports Key Milestones HYP.4.02.12 and HYP.4.01.18 of the Hypersonics Project under the NASA Fundamental Aeronautics Program.  SCOPE OF WORK: This effort is divided into two phases.  In the first phase, methods for evaluation of system-level uncertainty and for optimization with consideration of uncertainty will be developed.  In the second phase, the capability of the methods will be demonstrated on a system-level analysis, including the incorporation of selected increased-fidelity discipline analyses.  APPLICABLE DOCUMENTS/BACKGROUND: (a)	NASA Research Announcement (NRA) NNH07ZEA001N-HYP1.  DESCRIPTION OF TASKS/TECHNICAL REQUIREMENTS:  The Contractor shall perform the following tasks:  Task 1.0  Method Development 1.1 System-Level Uncertainty  1.1.1  The Contractor shall develop a minimum of one and no more than three candidate methods for the evaluation of system-level uncertainty that provides streamlined and rapid execution during optimization.  These candidate methods shall be discussed during telecon with NASA (see SOW 3.3), to review the benefits and issues with all of the candidate methods.  The Contractor shall use the candidate method mutually agreed upon by NASA and the Contractor for subsequent method development and demonstration of capability.  The selected method shall be approved in writing (via email) by the NASA COTR.  1.1.2 The Contactor shall develop software to implement the selected method and shall demonstrate the capability of this software on a subset of analyses selected from a system-level analysis.  The subset of analyses shall be mutually agreed upon by NASA and the Contractor and shall be approved in writing (via email) by the NASA COTR.  1.1.3	 The Contractor shall deliver the software (i.e., source code for ModelCenter modules and wrappers) along with documentation describing the methodology implemented in the software, the limitations of the software, and input and output parameters. (Attachment 3, Item 1)  1.2 Optimization with Uncertainty  1.2.1  The Contractor shall develop a method to incorporate an optimization process with consideration for uncertainty.  This method shall be discussed during telecon with NASA (see SOW 3.4), to review the benefits and issues of the method.  1.2.2	The Contactor shall develop software to implement this method and shall demonstrate the capability of this software on the previously agreed to subset of analyses selected from a system-level analysis.  1.2.3 The Contractor shall deliver the software (i.e., source code for ModelCenter modules and wrappers) along with documentation describing the methodology implemented in the software, the limitations of the software, and input and output parameters. (Attachment 3, Item 2)   Task 2.0  Method Application and Refinement  2.1 System-Level Analysis Demonstration  2.1.1 The Contractor shall apply the software developed in Tasks 1.1 and 1.2  to the evaluation of system-level uncertainty and system optimization with uncertainty on a hypersonic vehicle test case with selected discipline analysis tools.  The Contractor shall hold a telecon with NASA (see SOW 3.5) to specify a hypersonic vehicle system test case, including the system mission definition and to specify the selection of discipline analysis tools to be used in the evaluation of the methods.  The Contractor shall use the test case and discipline analysis tools mutually agreed upon by NASA and the Contractor for subsequent evaluation.  The test case and discipline analysis tools shall be approved in writing (via email) by the NASA COTR.  2.1.2 The Contactor shall modify and

Description of Work: NRA: NNH07ZEA001N-HYP1.  Proposal: 07-HYP-0083.  Entitled: Uncertainty Quantification and Propagation Methods and Tools for System-Level Analysis.  BACKGROUND:  The goal of this project is to develop an improved uncertainty analysis capability for hypersonic vehicles, including new methods for rapidly re-assessing hypersonic vehicle uncertainty after an initial detailed analysis.  This study supports Key Milestones HYP.4.02.10 and HYP.4.01.13 of the Hypersonics Project under the NASA Fundamental Aeronautics Program.  SCOPE OF WORK:  This effort is divided into two phases.  The focus of the first phase is the analysis of the system uncertainty of a full hypersonic vehicle analysis.  A description of uncertainty sources and an uncertainty analysis integration plan will be developed and implemented on an example hypersonic system study.    In the second phase, the data and analysis modules developed in the first phase will be used to generate new methods of rapidly reassessing system uncertainty given change in uncertainty assumptions.  The effectiveness of these rapid re-analysis methods will be assessed on representative test problem.  APPLICABLE DOCUMENTS/BACKGROUND:   (a) NASA Research Announcement (NRA) NNH07ZEA001N-HYP1.  DESCRIPTION OF TASKS/TECHNICAL REQUIREMENTS:  The Contractor shall perform the following tasks:  Task 1.0  Uncertainty Analysis  1.1 	Uncertainty Sources.  The Contractor shall develop a description of uncertainty sources for a detailed hypersonic system analysis, including uncertainty variables, levels and derivation methodology.  Categories of uncertainty sources shall include aerodynamics, propulsion, navigation, actuators, weights, atmosphere, cost, and operations.  This description shall be developed through consultation with subject matter experts from NASA.  A telecon shall be held to review the resulting description with NASA (see SOW 3.3). 1.2 	Uncertainty Analysis Plan   1.2.1	The Contractor shall develop an uncertainty analysis plan for a hypersonic vehicle.  This plan shall include modular uncertainty analysis algorithms separate from the basic vehicle analyses (i.e., performance, cost, reliability, and operability).   1.2.2	The Contactor shall develop an analysis integration plan with detailed analysis flows.  A telecon shall be held with NASA to review the uncertainty analysis plan (Task 1.2.1) and the analysis integration plan (see SOW 3.4).  The mutually agreed upon plans shall be approved in writing (via e-mail) by the NASA COTR. 1.3	Uncertainty Analysis Implementation 1.3.1	The Contractor shall develop prototype software for the implementation of the uncertainty sources and analysis plans of Tasks 1.1 and 1.2 on an example hypersonic vehicle system study.  A telecon shall be held to review the example system and analysis tools to be used in the study with NASA (see SOW 3.5),shall be mutually agreed upon by NASA and the Contractor, and approved in writing (via e-mail) by the NASA COTR.  1.3.2	The Contactor shall deliver the prototype uncertainty analysis software developed under Task 1.3.1 along with documentation describing the methodology implemented in the software, the limitations of the software, and input and output parameters.  (Attachment 3, Item 1)     Task 2.0	Rapid Re-analysis 2.1 	Generation of Candidate Methods for Rapid Re-analysis The Contractor shall develop between three and six candidate methods to rapidly assess the system impact of reductions in specific uncertainty variables due to improved analysis knowledge.  The results of Task 1.3 shall be screened to determine the drivers of system uncertainty to guide the development of the candidate methods.  A telecon shall be held with NASA to review the screening results and candidate methods (see SOW 3.6).  Three candidate methods to be tested shall be mutually agreed upon by NASA and the Contractor and approved in writing (via e-mail) by the NASA COTR.  2.2 	Rapid Re-analysis Testing 2.2.1	The Contractor shall t

Award Type: Delivery Order, Cost Plus Fixed Fee
Description of Work: THIS STATEMENT OF WORK (SOW) IS THE RESULT OF A PROPOSAL SUBMITTED BY BOEING ENGINEERING, OPERATIONS & TECHNOLOGY-PHANTOM WORKS FOR AWARD UNDER THE NASA HEADQUARTERS AERONAUTICS RESEARCH MISSION DIRECTORATE (ARMD) AMENDMENT NO. 2 TO THE NASA RESEARCH ANNOUNCEMENT (NRA) ENTITLED  RESEARCH OPPORTUNITIES IN AERONAUTICS    2008.   THIS EFFORT IS INTENDED TO IDENTIFY ADVANCED AIRFRAME AND PROPULSION CONCEPTS, AS WELL AS CORRESPONDING ENABLING TECHNOLOGIES FOR COMMERCIAL AIRCRAFT ANTICIPATED FOR ENTRY INTO SERVICE IN THE 2030-2035 TIMEFRAME ( N+3 ), MARKET PERMITTING.    THE CONTRACTOR SHALL PERFORM THE FOLLOWING REQUIREMENTS/TASKS:     TASK 1:  DEVELOP FUTURE SCENARIO.  THE CONTRACTOR SHALL CONDUCT AN ANALYSIS TO DELINEATE THE IMPLICATIONS OF THE NASA NEXTGEN 2030-2035 AIRSPACE SCENARIO.  THE CONTRACTOR SHALL CREATE A DETAILED DESCRIPTION OF THE WORLD S AIR TRAVEL MARKET CONDITIONS UNDER THE PASSENGER DEMAND CHARACTERISTICS IMPLIED BY ONGOING DEVELOPMENT OF THE NASA NEXTGEN N+3 AIRSPACE SCENARIO.  THE CONTRACTOR SHALL PERFORM THIS ANALYSIS USING ITS OWN ANNUALLY-UPDATED MARKET OUTLOOK THAT FORECASTS AIR TRAVEL GROWTH AND AIRCRAFT FLEET GROWTH, USING KEY ECONOMIC, DEMOGRAPHIC, GEOPOLITICAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS THAT CAPTURE THE GROWTH OF MEGA-CITIES, JET FUEL PRICE FLUCTUATIONS, EMISSION TRADING SCHEMES, NON-FOSSIL ENERGY PRODUCTION AND REGIONAL GROWTH EFFECTS.  USING TOOLS FOR ADVANCED NETWORK ANALYSIS, THE CONTRACTOR SHALL DESIGN AND EXECUTE A RANGE OF SIMULATIONS TO PRODUCE A SCIENTIFICALLY SOUND, STOCHASTIC REPRESENTATION OF THE DEMAND STRUCTURE TO BE MET BY THE SUBSONIC FAMILY OF AIRCRAFT THAT IS THE SUBJECT OF THIS STUDY.  THESE SIMULATIONS SHALL BE USED TO EVALUATE THE ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS OF ALTERNATIVE AIRPLANE, ENGINE AND PERFORMANCE CONFIGURATIONS ON A DETAILED, FLIGHT-BY-FLIGHT BASIS AND TO ESTIMATE THE REVENUE GENERATION POTENTIAL IN THE CONTEXT OF LIKELY DEMAND PATTERNS AND NETWORK TOPOLOGIES.    TASK 2:  DEVELOP ADVANCED VEHICLE CONCEPTS.  THE CONTRACTOR SHALL ESTABLISH SEVERAL REFERENCE AIRCRAFT CONCEPTS OF CONVENTIONAL CONFIGURATION (SINGLE CIRCULAR FUSELAGE, CANTILEVERED WING, SINGLE AFT-LOCATED HORIZONTAL AND VERTICAL TAILS, ENGINE MOUNTED BELOW THE WING OR ON THE AFT FUSELAGE) WITH STATE-OF-THE ART TECHNOLOGIES.  THE CONTRACTOR SHALL CONDUCT A WORKSHOP IN CONJUNCTION WITH ITS SUBCONTRACTORS AND NASA TO IDENTIFY THE PROS AND CONS OF EXISTING INNOVATIVE AIRCRAFT CONCEPTS, ENGINE CONCEPTS AND ARCHITECTURES, AND AIRCRAFT TECHNOLOGIES, AS WELL AS POSSIBLE NEW CONCEPTS, CONSISTENT WITH THE FUTURE SCENARIO SPECIFIED IN TASK 1.  IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE WORKSHOP PARTICIPANTS, THE CONTRACTOR SHALL SELECT FOR FURTHER ANALYSIS THOSE AIRCRAFT AND ENGINE CONCEPTS AND TECHNOLOGIES WHICH ARE EXPECTED TO MAKE SIGNIFICANT PROGRESS TOWARD ACHIEVING NASA S TECHNOLOGY GOALS FOR FUTURE SUBSONIC VEHICLES (TABLE 1).  THESE AIRCRAFT CONCEPTS TO BE CONSIDERED SHALL INCLUDE, BUT NOT BE LIMITED TO, THE STRUT-BRACED WING, BATTERY-POWERED ELECTRIC AIRLINERS, HYBRID-WING-BODY, HYDROGEN-POWERED AIRCRAFT, JOINED WING, AND METROPLEX-TYPE CONCEPT, AND OPERATIONAL VARIATIONS SUCH AS FORMATION FLIGHT AND IN-FLIGHT REFUELING.  AIRCRAFT TECHNOLOGIES TO BE CONSIDERED SHALL INCLUDE, BUT NOT BE LIMITED TO, MATERIALS AND STRUCTURES TECHNOLOGIES, AERODYNAMIC TECHNOLOGIES, AIRCRAFT SUBSYSTEM TECHNOLOGIES AND FUELS AND ENERGY STORAGE.    THE CONTRACTOR SHALL ANALYZE THE NOISE SOURCE CHARACTERISTICS OF THE REFERENCE AIRCRAFT AND SELECTED INNOVATIVE AIRCRAFT CONCEPTS DURING DEPARTURE AND ARRIVAL USING THE LATEST AIRCRAFT NOISE PREDICTION PROGRAM (ANOPP) SOURCE NOISE CODES AVAILABLE FROM NASA AND IN-HOUSE NOISE PREDICTION CODES OF THE CONTRACTOR AND SUBCONTRACTORS, INCLUDING THE EFFECTS OF ENGINE AND AIRFRAME INTEGRATIONS.  THE INCREMENTAL EFFECT OF ADVANCED PROPULSION CONCEPTS SHALL BE ESTIMATED BY THE CONTRACTOR USING STANDARD TOOLS AND DATABASES WHERE APPLICABLE, OR USING APPROPRIATE SCALING AND ENGINEERING JUDGMENT. Description of Work: STRUCTURES, MATERIALS, AERODYNAMICS, AEROTHERMODYNAMICS AND ACOUSTICS RESEARCH AND TECHNOLOGY (SMAAART).  THIS CONTRACT IS FOR STRUCTURES, MATERIALS, AERODYNAMICS, AEROTHERMODYNAMICS, AND ACOUSTICS RESEARCH AND TECHNOLOGY FOR AEROSPACE VEHICLES. THE CONTRACTOR SHALL FURNISH ALL PERSONNEL, FACILITIES, EQUIPMENT, MATERIAL, SUPPLIES, AND SERVICES, EXCEPT AS MAY BE EXPRESSLY SET FORTH IN THE CONTRACT TASK ORDERS AS GOVERNMENT FURNISHED, AND OTHERWISE DO ALL THINGS NECESSARY TO, OR INCIDENT TO, PERFORM AND PROVIDE THE WORK EFFORTS DESCRIBED IN THE PWS.  THE CONTRACTOR SHALL PERFORM TASK ORDERS THAT ARE ISSUED BY THE LANGLEY RESEARCH CENTER CONTRACTING OFFICER.  THIS CONTRACT MAY BE USED TO SUPPORT ALL NASA CENTERS THAT REQUIRE WORK WITHIN THE SCOPE OF THE PWS.  STRUCTURES AND MATERIALS - SUPPORT RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT IN MATERIALS AND STRUCTURES TECHNOLOGY RELATED TO AEROSPACE VEHICLES, WITH EMPHASIS IN THE RESEARCH AREAS OF STRUCTURAL MECHANICS AND CONCEPTS, DURABILITY, DAMAGE TOLERANCE, AND RELIABILITY, STRUCTURAL DYNAMICS, AEROELASTICITY, ADVANCED MATERIALS AND PROCESSING, AND NONDESTRUCTIVE EVALUATION SCIENCES.  DURABILITY, DAMAGE TOLERANCE, AND RELIABILITY - INVESTIGATE STABILITY, STRENGTH, DAMAGE TOLERANCE, AND STRUCTURAL INTEGRITY OF AIRCRAFT AND SPACECRAFT STRUCTURES, AND TAILOR STRUCTURES MADE FROM COMPOSITE, METALLIC OR HYBRID METALLIC-COMPOSITE MATERIALS.  STRUCTURAL DYNAMICS - ANALYTICAL AND EXPERIMENTAL RESEARCH FOR THE PURPOSE OF DEVELOPING AND VALIDATING IMPROVED METHODS TO PREDICT, VERIFY, AND CONTROL COMPLEX AIRCRAFT AND SPACE STRUCTURES DYNAMIC RESPONSES, AND TO CONFIRM THE VALIDITY OF APPROACHES BY CONDUCTING TESTS ON FULL-SCALE STRUCTURES, STRUCTURAL ELEMENTS, AND SCALED STRUCTURAL MODELS.  AEROELASTICITY - STUDY AEROELASTIC PHENOMENA AND PREDICTION CAPABILITIES NEEDED TO APPLY NEW AERODYNAMICS AND STRUCTURAL CONCEPTS TO FUTURE FLIGHT VEHICLES AND TO DETERMINE AND SOLVE THE AEROELASTIC PROBLEMS OF CURRENT DESIGNS. STRUCTURAL MECHANICS AND CONCEPTS - ANALYTICAL AND EXPERIMENTAL RESEARCH TO STUDY THE BEHAVIOR OF COMPLEX STRUCTURES SUBJECT TO STATIC AND TIME-VARYING MECHANICAL AND THERMAL LOADS.  ADVANCED MATERIALS AND PROCESSING - FUNDAMENTAL AND APPLIED MATERIALS AND PROCESSING RESEARCH STUDIES THAT COVER THE DEVELOPMENT AND INTEGRATION OF THE FULL RANGE OF AEROSPACE MATERIALS (POLYMERS, METALS, CERAMICS, COMPOSITES DERIVED FROM COMBINATIONS OF ANY OF THE THREE AREAS AND EMERGING MATERIALS TECHNOLOGIES) INTO AEROSPACE SYSTEMS.  NONDESTRUCTIVE EVALUATION SCIENCES - RESEARCH, DEVELOP, AND APPLY ADVANCED MEASUREMENT TECHNIQUES THAT RELATE QUANTITATIVE NONDESTRUCTIVE EVALUATION SCIENCES TO PHYSICAL/ENGINEERING MATERIALS AND STRUCTURES CHARACTERIZATION. AERODYNAMIC, AEROTHERMODYNAMIC AND ACOUSTICS - SUPPORT RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT IN AERODYNAMICS, AEROTHERMODYNAMICS, AND ACOUSTICS TECHNOLOGY RELATED TO AEROSPACE VEHICLES, WITH EMPHASIS IN THE RESEARCH AREAS OF CONFIGURATION AERODYNAMICS, COMPUTATIONAL MODELING AND SIMULATION, FLOW PHYSICS AND CONTROL, AIRCRAFT AND SPACECRAFT NOISE AND VIBRATION PREDICTION AND CONTROL, AEROTHERMODYNAMICS, HYPERSONIC AIRBREATHING PROPULSION, ADVANCED MEASUREMENT, DIAGNOSTICS, AND INSTRUMENT SYSTEMS, AND MODEL SYSTEMS.  CONFIGURATION AERODYNAMICS - APPLIED EXPERIMENTAL AND COMPUTATIONAL RESEARCH FOCUSED ON THE DEVELOPMENT OF ADVANCED CONFIGURATION CONCEPTS FOR ALL CLASSES OF FIXED-WING AIRCRAFT AT SUBSONIC, TRANSONIC, AND SUPERSONIC SPEEDS. COMPUTATIONAL MODELING AND SIMULATION -  DEVELOP COMPUTATIONAL METHODS THAT CAN BE USED TO IMPROVE FUNDAMENTAL UNDERSTANDING OF PHYSICS ASSOCIATED WITH THE FLUID MECHANICS AND NOISE GENERATION FOR COMPLEX AIRFRAME SYSTEMS.  FLOW PHYSICS AND CONTROL - CONDUCT FUNDAMENTAL EXPERIMENTAL AND COMPUTATIONAL RESEARCH TO ENHANCE THE KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING OF THE PHYSICS UNDERLYING BOUNDARY-LAYER TRANSITION, ACTIVE AND PASSIVE FLOW CONTROL, THREE-DIMENSIONAL FLOW PHYSICS, TURBULENCE, VORTICAL AND SEPARATED FLOWS. AIRCRAFT AND SPACECRAFT NOISE PREDICTIO

Description of Work: SMAAART TASK ORDER.  TASK TITLE:  ACOUSTIC PANEL FABRICATION.  1.0	INTRODUCTION/BACKGROUND:  DUE TO THEIR LIGHTWEIGHT AND HIGH STIFFNESS CHARACTERISTICS, COMPOSITE STRUCTURES ARE VERY EFFICIENT IN RADIATING AND TRANSMITTING NOISE.  THE STRUCTURAL CONCEPT UNDER DEVELOPMENT IN THIS TASK IS THE PULTRUDED ROD STITCHED EFFICIENT UNITIZED STRUCTURE (PRSEUS) WHICH IS STITCHED TOGETHER AND THEN INFUSED WITH RESIN TO CREATE A CONTINUOUS CO-CURED COMPOSITION.  THE NOISE TRANSMISSION CHARACTERISTICS OF THE PRSEUS STRUCTURE MAY BE EVEN MORE PRONOUNCED THAN OTHER COMPOSITE STRUCTURES.  SINCE SUCH STRUCTURES CAN EXHIBIT NOISE RADIATION PATTERNS THAT ARE VERY DIFFERENT FROM OTHER BOLTED OR BONDED COMPOSITE SKIN-STRINGER AND/OR SANDWICH PANELS, THE VIBRO-ACOUSTIC BEHAVIOR OF SUCH STRUCTURES MUST BE EXAMINED USING ANALYTICAL AND EXPERIMENTAL TECHNIQUES.  THE INTENT IS TO UNDERSTAND THE FUNDAMENTAL PANEL RESPONSE FOR NOISE ATTENUATION, AND THEN TO DEVELOP TECHNIQUES THAT COULD BE USED TO MITIGATE VIBRATION AND NOISE PROBLEMS THAT MAY ARISE IN THEIR FULL-SCALE APPLICATIONS.   2.0 	SCOPE / OBJECTIVES:  THE MAIN OBJECTIVES OF THIS TASK ORDER SHALL BE TO DEFINE THE DESIRED NOISE TRANSMISSION PROPERTIES AND ENVIRONMENTS FOR THE HYBRID WING BODY (HWB) STRUCTURE AND CABIN, INVESTIGATE ALTERNATE NOISE MITIGATION STRATEGIES, AND TO FABRICATE A PRSEUS TEST PANEL THAT SHALL BE DELIVERED TO NASA LARC FOR TESTING IN THE STRUCTURAL ACOUSTICS LOADS AND TRANSMISSION (SALT) ACOUSTICS TEST FACILITY.   3.0	DESCRIPTION OF THE WORK/TASKS TO BE PERFORMED:    THE CONTRACTOR SHALL PERFORM THE FOLLOWING TASKS:      3.1	ADVANCED CONCEPT DEVELOPMENT THE CONTRACTOR SHALL INCLUDE WRITE-UPS FOR EACH OF THE FOLLOWING AREAS TO BE INCLUDED IN THE FINAL REPORT.  (DELIVERABLE ITEM 4.5)  3.1.1 	NOISE CONSTRAINTS AND REQUIREMENTS - VIBRO-ACOUSTIC BEHAVIOR OF PRSEUS COMPOSITE STRUCTURES IS NOT FULLY UNDERSTOOD.  IN THIS TASK, NOISE AND VIBRATION ATTENUATION CONSTRAINTS AND REQUIREMENTS FOR PRSEUS STRUCTURES IN TERMS OF SOUND POWER AND RADIATION WHEN COMPARED WITH METALLIC STRUCTURES, SHALL BE DESCRIBED.  EXPERIMENTAL TECHNIQUES AND PARAMETERS TO QUANTIFY NOISE AND VIBRATION CHARACTERISTICS OF A COMPOSITE PRSEUS PANEL SHALL ALSO BE DESCRIBED.        3.1.2 	ANALYSIS MODEL THE CONTRACTOR SHALL USE NASTRAN FINITE ELEMENT MODEL DECK TYPICAL OF HYBRID WING BODY AIRCRAFT FUSELAGE CONSTRUCTION TO BE USED AS A STARTING POINT FOR DEVELOPMENT OF A NASA DERIVED STRUCTURAL ACOUSTIC MODEL.    NOTE:  THE CONTRACTOR PREVIOUSLY DEVELOPED THIS MODEL AND FUSELAGE CONSTRUCTION UNDER NASA CONTRACT NNL07AA48C.  3.1.3 	CONTROL CONCEPTS DUE TO THE UNIQUE GEOMETRY AND CONSTRUCTION TECHNIQUES EMPLOYED TO BUILD PRSEUS STRUCTURES, THE POTENTIAL EXISTS TO INCLUDE ADVANCED NOISE TREATMENTS AS AN INTEGRAL ELEMENT OF THE LOAD-BEARING STRUCTURE.  THE CONTRACTOR SHALL USE INTEGRAL DAMPENING TECHNIQUES, SUCH AS VIBRO-ACOUSTIC LAYERS AND/OR RIGID CORE MATERIALS IN THE SKIN, TO CONCEPTUALLY DEVELOP AND EXHIBIT DIFFERENT ALTERNATIVES FOR EFFICIENTLY REDUCING SOUND TRANSMISSION THROUGH PRSEUS STRUCTURES.         3.2	ACOUSTIC TEST PANEL - THE CONTRACTOR SHALL DESIGN AND BUILD A 4-FT BY 4-FT PRSEUS ACOUSTIC TEST PANEL WITH 2 FRAMES 24 INCHES APART AND 8 ROD STIFFENERS 6 INCHES APART THAT IS REPRESENTATIVE OF A HWB FUSELAGE SHELL AND DELIVER THAT ARTICLE TO NASA LARC FOR TESTING AS FOLLOWS:    3.2.1 	DESIGN AND ANALYSIS - A DETAILED DRAWING OF THE TEST PANEL AND A TEST SPECIFICATION WRITE-UP SHALL BE PREPARED AND INCLUDED IN THE FINAL REPORT (DELIVERABLE ITEM 4.5).  THE PANEL GEOMETRY SHALL BE DESIGNED FOR INSTALLATION INTO THE TEST WINDOW FRAME AT THE SALT FACILITY AT NASA LARC (SEE SOW 5.1 GFI).    3.2.2 	TOOLING PREPARATION - AN EXISTING TOOL SET (SEE SOW 6.0 GFP) SHALL BE MODIFIED TO FABRICATE THE PANEL.  NEW DISPOSABLE STRINGER MANDRELS SHALL BE FABRICATED TO ACCOMMODATE FOR THE UNIQUE DOUBLER BUILD-UPS AROUND THE ENTIRE PERIMETER OF THE PANEL.  3.2.3 	PANEL FABRICATION - THE CONT

Description of Work: TAS::80 0123::TAS RECOVERY ACT FUNDS RECOVERY - SMAAART TASK TITLE:  COMPOSITE CRYOTANK TECHNOLOGIES AND DEMONSTRATION DESIGN, ANALYSIS, AND TESTING FOR COMPOSITE LH2 CRYOTANKS   1.0	BACKGROUND  NASA IS EXPLORING ADVANCED COMPOSITE MATERIALS AND PROCESSES TO REDUCE THE OVERALL COST AND WEIGHT OF LIQUID HYDROGEN (LH2) CRYOTANKS. COMPOSITES ARE MATERIALS THAT ARE COMBINATIONS OF TWO OR MORE ORGANIC OR INORGANIC COMPONENTS. ONE MATERIAL SERVES AS A \MATRIX,\" WHICH IS THE MATERIAL THAT HOLDS EVERYTHING TOGETHER, WHILE THE OTHER MATERIAL SERVES AS REINFORCEMENT, IN THE FORM OF FIBERS EMBEDDED IN THE MATRIX.  A CRYOTANK IS A CONTAINER THAT CAN STORE VERY COLD LIQUIDS, IN THIS CASE LIQUID HYDROGEN.  THE ULTIMATE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE NEW AND INNOVATIVE CRYOTANK TECHNOLOGIES THAT ENABLE HUMAN SPACE EXPLORATION TO DESTINATIONS BEYOND LOW EARTH ORBIT SUCH AS THE MOON, NEAR-EARTH ASTEROIDS, AND MARS.  THE FOCUS OF THIS INITIAL 1-YEAR EFFORT IS TO RESEARCH AND DEVELOP THE COMPOSITE CRYOTANK TECHNOLOGIES REQUIRED FOR A HEAVY LIFT LAUNCH VEHICLE (SIMILAR TO THE SATURN V ROCKET USED TO LAUNCH APOLLO MISSIONS) BETWEEN 8.4 METERS AND 10.0 METERS IN DIAMETER.  THIS TECHNOLOGY WILL SERVE MULTIPLE CUSTOMERS INCLUDING NASA, THE DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE (DOD), AND COMMERCIAL AEROSPACE COMPANIES.  FUTURE SPIN-OFF CAPABILITIES MAY INCLUDE LH2 CORE STAGES (1ST AND TYPICALLY LARGEST SECTION OF A ROCKET), IN-SPACE PROPULSION SYSTEMS (A PROPULSION SYSTEM IS A MACHINE THAT PRODUCES THRUST TO PUSH AN OBJECT FORWARD), ON-ORBIT PROPELLANT DEPOTS (A CACHE OF PROPELLANT THAT IS PLACED ON AN ORBIT ABOUT THE EARTH OR ANOTHER BODY TO ALLOW SPACECRAFT TO BE FUELLED IN SPACE), AND LIQUID OXYGEN (LOX) CRYOTANKS.    OVER THE PAST 15 YEARS, THERE HAVE BEEN A VARIETY OF COMPOSITE CRYOGENIC TANK PROGRAMS AT NASA AND THE AIR FORCE.  EACH OF THESE PROJECTS HAS HAD SOME SUCCESS BUT THERE HAVE ALSO BEEN TECHNOLOGY CHALLENGES THAT HAVE MADE NASA RELUCTANT TO INCORPORATE THEM.  ONE OF THE GREATEST CHALLENGES THAT NASA FACES WHEN INCORPORATING ANY ADVANCED TECHNOLOGY IS BRIDGING THE MID TECHNICAL READINESS LEVEL (TRL AS DEFINED BY HTTP://ESTO.NASA.GOV/FILES/TRL_DEFINITIONS.PDF) GAP BETWEEN EARLY DEVELOPMENT AND INCORPORATION INTO FLIGHT VEHICLES (ROCKETS).  THE INTENT OF THIS CONTRACT EFFORT IS TO PUSH THE TECHNICAL MATURITY OF COMPOSITE TANKS FURTHER BY BUILDING ON THE DEVELOPMENTS OF RECENT PROGRAMS.  NASAS MOST RECENT COMPOSITE CRYOTANK WAS DEVELOPED UNDER THE NEXT GENERATION LAUNCH TECHNOLOGY (NGLT) PROJECT.  THE COMPOSITE CRYOTANK TECHNOLOGIES AND DEMONSTRATION (CCTD) ALSO HAS THE OPPORTUNITY TO BUILD ON NEW IMPROVEMENTS DEVELOPED BY COMMERCIAL AEROSPACE INTERNAL RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT (IR&D) ACTIVITIES AS WELL AS LEVERAGING TECHNOLOGY INVESTMENTS OF INTERNATIONAL AND ACADEMIC PARTNERS, AND OTHER GOVERNMENT AGENCIES.  BUILDING ON PAST COMPOSITE CRYOTANK SUCCESSES AND EVALUATING NEW STATE OF THE ART MATERIALS THROUGH EQUIVALENCY TESTING SHOULD ALLOW NASA TO REALIZE CONSIDERABLE MASS AND COST SAVINGS.  IN FISCAL YEAR 2011, NASA PLANS TO BEGIN A PROGRAM THAT FOCUSES ON INNOVATIVE IDEAS ENABLING NEW CAPABILITIES OR RADICALLY ALTERING OUR CURRENT APPROACHES TO SPACE SYSTEMS.  GAME CHANGING DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS (GCDP) ARE INTENDED TO BE CAPABILITY-ORIENTED AND DIFFER FROM TRADITIONAL RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT METHODS THAT ADVANCE DISCIPLINE OR CORE KNOWLEDGE.  THE GOAL OF THE PLANNED GCDP IS TO MATURE TECHNOLOGIES IN PREPARATION FOR POTENTIAL SYSTEM LEVEL FLIGHT DEMONSTRATIONS THROUGH SIGNIFICANT GROUND-BASED TESTING AND/OR LABORATORY EXPERIMENTATION.  NASA WILL MANAGE THE COMPOSITE CRYOTANK TECHNOLOGIES AND DEMONSTRATION PROJECT WITHIN THESE GUIDELINES.    THE CCTD PROJECT WILL BE SPLIT INTO TWO PHASES.  THE CURRENT EFFORT DESCRIBED IN THIS SOW IS PHASE 1.     THE SUCCESSFUL COMPLETION OF PHASE 1 COULD RESULT IN NASA ISSUING A SEPARATE 2-YEAR CONTRACT FOR PHASE 2 IF FUNDS ARE AVAILABLE.  PHASE 2 WILL LIKELY INVOLVE THE CRITICAL DESIGN, ANALYSIS, AND MANUFA"

Description of Work: IGF::OT::IGF     TASK ORDER - STATEMENT OF WORK (SOW)  TASK TITLE: HYBRID WING BODY ENGINE/AIRFRAME OPERABILITY TESTING  1.0	INTRODUCTION/BACKGROUND:  THE ENVIRONMENTALLY RESPONSIBLE AVIATION (ERA) PROJECT WITHIN THE INTEGRATED SYSTEMS RESEARCH PROGRAM (ISRP) OF THE NASA AERONAUTICS RESEARCH MISSION DIRECTORATE (ARMD) HAS THE RESPONSIBILITY TO EXPLORE AND DOCUMENT THE FEASIBILITY, BENEFITS, AND TECHNICAL RISK OF VEHICLE CONCEPTS AND ENABLING TECHNOLOGIES THAT WILL REDUCE THE IMPACT OF AVIATION ON THE ENVIRONMENT.  THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THE ERA PROJECT IS TO SELECT VEHICLE CONCEPTS AND TECHNOLOGIES THAT CAN SIMULTANEOUSLY REDUCE NOISE, FUEL BURN, AND EMISSIONS.  IN ADDITION, THE ERA PROJECT WILL IDENTIFY AND MITIGATE TECHNICAL RISK AND TRANSFER KNOWLEDGE TO THE AERONAUTICS COMMUNITY AT LARGE SO THAT NEW TECHNOLOGIES AND VEHICLE CONCEPTS CAN BE INCORPORATED INTO THE FUTURE DESIGN OF AIRCRAFT.  THE ERA PROJECT IS A 6-YEAR, TWO-PHASE PROJECT WITH SEVERAL INTEGRATED TECHNOLOGY DEMONSTRATION (ITD) WORK PACKAGES THAT ARE CURRENTLY DEFINED FOR PHASE II (FY13-FY15).    THE ERA PROJECT (PHASE I) CONCLUDED AN ADVANCED VEHICLE CONCEPTS (AVC) STUDY IN JANUARY 2012 UNDER NASA DRYDEN CONTRACT NND11AG03C WITH BOEING THAT IDENTIFIED ADVANCED INTEGRATED VEHICLE CONCEPTS AND COMPONENT TECHNOLOGY CONCEPTS THAT WILL ALLOW SUBSONIC TRANSPORT AIRCRAFT TO SIMULTANEOUSLY MEET THE NASA SYSTEM LEVEL GOALS OF REDUCED NOISE, EMISSIONS, AND FUEL BURN IN THE 2025 (OR BEYOND) TIMEFRAME.  BOEINGS FINAL REPORT UNDER THIS CONTRACT DEFINED A HYBRID WING BODY (HWB) PREFERRED SYSTEM CONCEPT VEHICLE THAT SIMULTANEOUSLY ACHIEVED ALL SYSTEM LEVEL GOALS.  IN THAT SYSTEM STUDY, MANY ASSUMPTIONS WERE MADE AS TO THE INSTALLATION EFFECTS OF ULTRA HIGH BYPASS RATIO (UHBR) RATIO ENGINES ON THE UPPER SURFACE OF THE VEHICLE CONCEPT.  THERE IS SIGNIFICANT UNCERTAINTY IN MANY OF THOSE ASSUMPTIONS.  IN ADDITION, MANY OTHER IMPORTANT ASPECTS OF ENGINE AIRFRAME INTEGRATION WERE BEYOND THE SCOPE OF THE NASA DRYDEN AVC STUDY.  ISSUES LIKE INSTALLATION DRAG INCREMENTS ON VEHICLE PERFORMANCE AND FOREBODY DOMINATED FLOWS (ESPECIALLY AT LOW SPEEDS AND HIGH ANGLES OF ATTACK AND SIDESLIP) COULD HAVE SIGNIFICANT IMPACT ON THE OPERABILITY OF UHBR ENGINES MOUNTED ON THE UPPER SURFACE OF HWB ADVANCED VEHICLE CONCEPTS.  THESE PROPULSION/AIRFRAME INTEGRATION (PAI) DRIVEN ISSUES MUST BE EXAMINED TO REDUCE THE UNCERTAINTY IN THE AVCS PERFORMANCE AND WILL BE THE FOCUS OF PAI EFFORTS CONDUCTED IN ERA PHASE II.     THE PLANNING PROCESS FOR ERA PROJECT PHASE II INVOLVED SEVERAL KEY DECISION POINTS WHERE VARIOUS TECHNOLOGIES WERE EVALUATED AND SOME WERE SELECTED FOR FURTHER DEVELOPMENT UNDER SEVERAL ITD WORK PACKAGES.  ONE OF THOSE ITD WORK PACKAGES GIVEN AUTHORITY TO PROCEED BY ARMD INCLUDED THE ASSESSMENT OF UHBR ENGINE OPERABILITY ON A HWB ADVANCED VEHICLE CONCEPT.  AS PART OF THIS ITD WORK PACKAGE, THE SPACE ACT AGREEMENT (SAA) SAA1-1018, ANNEX 7 PLANS TO CAPTURE A COLLABORATIVE AGREEMENT BETWEEN BOEING AND NASA.  UNDER THE SAA, BOEING WILL FURNISH THE HWB MODEL AND NASA WILL FACILITATE THE 14X22 WIND TUNNEL FOR TWO EXPERIMENT TEST CAMPAIGNS.  IN ADDITION, NASA WILL FURNISH A SET OF TURBINE-POWERED SIMULATOR SYSTEMS FOR THE TESTS.    2.0 	SCOPE&OBJECTIVE(S):  THE SCOPE OF THIS TASK ORDER IS TO DEVELOP DETAILED TEST REQUIREMENTS AND PERFORM COMPUTATIONAL ANALYSIS FOR EXPERIMENT DEVELOPMENT FOR A SUBSCALE WIND TUNNEL EXPERIMENT WITH TWO TEST CAMPAIGNS THAT NASA AND BOEING WILL CONDUCT UNDER THE SAA1-1018, ANNEX 7.  THESE TESTS ARE REQUIRED TO UNDERSTAND OPERABILITY ISSUES THAT MIGHT RESULT FROM THE PAI OF AN UHBR ENGINE ON A LOW-NOISE HWB ADVANCED VEHICLE CONFIGURATION AS WELL AS THE LOW SPEED PERFORMANCE RESULTING FROM SUCH INTEGRATION.  THE TWO TEST CAMPAIGNS ARE DESCRIBED AS FOLLOWS:      	FLOW-THRU NACELLE (FTN) AND EJECTOR TEST CAMPAIGN: AN ENGINE AIRFRAME OPERABILITY TEST AT KEY LOW SPEED OPERATING CONDITIONS FOR THE MEASUREMENT AND CHARACTERIZATION OF INLET FLOW DISTORTION AND

Description of Work: IGF::OT::IGF     TASK ORDER - STATEMENT OF WORK (SOW)  TASK TITLE:  BOEING LCAT ARC JET TEST IN SUPPORT OF FLEXIBLE TPS EVALUATION AND DEVELOPMENT  1.0	INTRODUCTION / BACKGROUND:  THE HYPERSONIC INFLATABLE AERODYNAMIC DECELERATOR (HIAD) PROJECT IS A TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPMENT EFFORT INVESTIGATING THE VIABILITY AND SURVIVABILITY OF INFLATABLE AERODYNAMIC DECELERATORS AT FLIGHT RELEVANT ENVIRONMENTS FOR APPLICATION TO FUTURE PLANETARY ENTRY SPACECRAFT.  IN ORDER TO EVALUATE A FLEXIBLE THERMAL PROTECTION SYSTEMS (FTPS), WHICH IS THE HEAT SHIELD FOR THE HIAD, THE FTPS MUST BE SUBJECTED TO FLIGHT-RELEVANT HEATING, PRESSURES, AND SHEARING ENVIRONMENTS EXPERIENCED DURING REENTRY, AND SHOW MARGINED PERFORMANCE AND SURVIVAL.  IN SUPPORT OF THE HIAD PROJECTS FLEXIBLE SYSTEMS TECHNICAL DEVELOPMENT AREA, THE NASA LANGLEY RESEARCH CENTER (LARC) ENGINEERING GROUP IS MODELING, TESTING, AND VERIFYING MODELING OF FTPS LAYUPS IN FLIGHT RELEVANT REACTIVE FLOW ENVIRONMENTS IN ORDER TO ESTABLISH A MODELING PARADIGM AND A MORE EFFECTIVE MARGIN POLICY FOR INFLATABLE AND RIGID REENTRY SYSTEMS.  SPECIFIC NASA PROVIDED SPECIMENS, (MADE UP OF VARIOUS LAYUP COMBINATIONS OF ADVANCED FLEXIBLE MATERIALS) ARE MODELED AND TESTED IN FLIGHT RELEVANT CONDITIONS FOR MODEL VERIFICATION AND MARGIN MATURATION.    THIS EFFORT BUILDS UPON TESTING ALREADY CONDUCTED AT THE LCAT UNDER BOEINGS SMAAART CONTRACT NNL10AA05B, TASK ORDER NNL11AD16T, ENTITLED BOEING LCAT ARC-JET TEST IN SUPPORT OF FLEXIBLE TPS EVALUATION AND DEVELOPMENT.   UNDER NNL11AD16T, HUNDREDS OF  FTPS SAMPLES HAVE BEEN EVALUATED AT SEVERAL CONDITIONS OF DEVELOPMENT INTEREST, ESTABLISHING A BASIS FOR THE CRITICAL ADVANCEMENT OF THE SUCCESSFUL FLIGHT OF THE INFLATABLE REENTRY VEHICLE EXPERIMENT (IRVE)-3 IN JULY 2012 AND ADVANCING THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE NEXT GENERATION OF FTPS.  THE TESTING DESCRIBED BY THIS SOW WILL CONTINUE THIS CRUCIAL ADVANCEMENT BY BUILDING UPON THE DATABASE OF RESULTS ALREADY OBTAINED.  FURTHER TESTING IS NEEDED TO COMPARE MORE ADVANCED MATERIALS AND LAYUPS WITH PREVIOUSLY TESTED COUPONS AND TO EXTEND THE HEAT FLUX AND PRESSURE TEST RANGE, SIMULATING HARSHER ATMOSPHERIC REENTRY FLIGHT ENVIRONMENTS.  2.0 	SCOPE&OBJECTIVE(S):  THE SCOPE OF THIS TASK ORDER IS TO EVALUATE FTPS LAYUPS AND MATERIALS AT COMPARABLE OR HARSHER SIMULATED ATMOSPHERIC REENTRY FLIGHT CONDITIONS AND RIGID DEPLOYABLE TPS LAYUPS AND MATERIALS AT MUCH HARSHER SIMULATED ATMOSPHERIC REENTRY FLIGHT CONDITIONS.  FTPS MATERIALS AND SYSTEMS WILL BE TESTED UTILIZING THE LCAT FACILITY FOR 12 WEEKS OF TOTAL TEST TIME AT FOUR SPECIFIC TEST CONDITIONS WHICH SIMULATE RELEVANT TEST ENVIRONMENTS. THE FIRST TWO TEST CONDITIONS, GIVEN IN OBJECTIVES 1 AND 2 BELOW, WERE DEVELOPED UNDER TASK ORDER NNL11AD16T.  NEW MATERIALS AND SYSTEMS WILL BE COMPARED AT THESE CONDITIONS.  THE REMAINING TWO TEST CONDITIONS ARE NEW TEST REQUIREMENTS OUTLINED IN OBJECTIVES 3 AND 4 BELOW TO EXTEND THE RANGE OF THE CURRENT MATERIALS AND SYSTEMS DATA BASE.  THE OBJECTIVES FOR THIS TASK ORDER ARE AS FOLLOWS:  OBJECTIVE ONE:	EVALUATION OF FTPS LAYUPS AND MATERIALS AT FLIGHT-LIKE CONDITIONS SIMULATING A HEAT FLUX ENTRY CONDITION (SQUARE PULSE OR MISSION PROFILE IN STAGNATION OR SHEAR) OF<50 W/CM2 (HEAT FLUX BETWEEN #tilde#17 AND<50 W/CM2, PRESSURE BETWEEN #tilde#1.7 AND #tilde#10KPA).  OBJECTIVE TWO:	EVALUATION OF FTPS LAYUPS AND MATERIALS AT FLIGHT-LIKE CONDITIONS SIMULATING A HEAT FLUX ENTRY CONDITION (SQUARE PULSE OR MISSION PROFILE IN STAGNATION OR SHEAR) OF #tilde#50 W/CM2 (HEAT FLUX #tilde#50 W/CM2, PRESSURE #tilde#6KPA).  OBJECTIVE THREE:	EVALUATION OF FTPS LAYUPS AND MATERIALS AT FLIGHT-LIKE CONDITIONS SIMULATING A HEAT FLUX ENTRY CONDITION (SQUARE PULSE OR MISSION PROFILE IN STAGNATION OR SHEAR) OF #tilde#75 W/CM2 (HEAT FLUX #tilde#75W/CM2, PRESSURE #tilde#10KPA).  OBJECTIVE FOUR:	EVALUATION OF FTPS LAYUPS AND MATERIALS AT FLIGHT-LIKE CONDITIONS SIMULATING A HEAT FLUX ENTRY CONDITION (SQUARE PULSE IN STAGNATION) OF #tilde#130 W/CM2 (HEAT FLUX #tilde#130 W/CM2, PRESSURE BETWEEN #tilde#6 AND #tilde#12K

Description of Work: IGF::OT::IGF     TASK ORDER - STATEMENT OF WORK (SOW)  TASK TITLE: FLIGHT SERVICES AND AIRCRAFT ACCESS INTRODUCTION/BACKGROUND: THE PURPOSE OF THE OVERALL ACTIVITY UNDERTAKEN BY THE NASA ENVIRONMENTALLY RESPONSIBLE AVIATION (ERA) PROJECT AND THE CONTRACTOR IS TO DETERMINE THE APPLICABILITY OF ACTIVE SEPARATION CONTROL TO COMMERCIAL AIRCRAFT OPERATION, CONSIDERING THAT AERODYNAMIC PERFORMANCE, SYSTEM INTEGRATION COMPLEXITY, AND SYSTEM COSTS IN TERMS OF REQUIRED ENERGY ARE PART OF THE DECISION PROCESS.   VERTICAL TAIL SIZING ON COMMERCIAL AIRCRAFT IS DRIVEN, IN LARGE PART, BY PERFORMANCE REQUIRED FOR EMERGENCY SITUATIONS AND/OR OPERATIONS NEAR THE EDGES OF THE FLIGHT ENVELOPE.  FOR AIRCRAFT WHERE THE ENGINES ARE MOUNTED ON THE WINGS, ENGINE-OUT CONDITIONS RELY HEAVILY ON THE RUDDER TO PROVIDE SUFFICIENT YAWING MOMENT TO TRIM OUT THE AIRPLANE.  AS PART OF THE ENVIRONMENTALLY RESPONSIBLE AVIATION (ERA) PROJECT, NASA IS SEEKING TO DEMONSTRATE THE POTENTIAL BENEFITS OF REDUCING VERTICAL TAIL SIZE THROUGH THE USE OF ACTIVE FLOW CONTROL (AFC). THE AFC-ENABLED VERTICAL TAIL WOULD UTILIZE AFC TO PROVIDE REQUIRED PERFORMANCE AT FLIGHT CONDITIONS THAT DRIVE THE SIZING OF THE VERTICAL TAIL WHILE OPERATING IN A CONVENTIONAL MANNER AT ALL OTHER FLIGHT CONDITIONS. AS PART OF THE ERA PROJECT, NASA ALSO IS SEEKING TO DEMONSTRATE THE POTENTIAL BENEFITS OF INSECT ACCRETION AND MITIGATION (IAM) (INSECT PROTECTION).  IAM COATING TECHNOLOGIES ARE USED TO MITIGATE WING AND LEADING EDGE INSECT RESIDUE ADHESION IN ORDER TO ENHANCE AND MAINTAIN WING LAMINAR FLOW. ONE OF THE CHALLENGES FOR THE IMPLEMENTATION OF WING LAMINAR FLOW IS PREMATURE LOSS OF LAMINAR FLOW FROM ROUGHNESS INDUCED BY INSECT CONTAMINATION.   NASA WILL FLIGHT TEST BOTH THE AFC MASS FLOW DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM (AFC SYSTEM) AND IAM COATING TECHNOLOGIES ON A COMMERCIAL AIRLINER VERTICAL TAIL AND WING RESPECTIVELY, WITH THE CONTRACTOR PROVIDING FLIGHT SERVICES AND AIRCRAFT ACCESS.  THE FLIGHT TESTS ARE EXPECTED TO OCCUR NO EARLIER THAN AUGUST 2014. 2	SCOPE, OBJECTIVES, APPLICABLE DOCUMENTS, AND DEFINITIONS FOR TERMS AND ACRONYMS: 2.1	SCOPE: THE SCOPE OF THIS TASK ORDER IS TO FABRICATE, INSTALL, AND FLIGHT TEST AFC AND IAM TECHNOLOGIES ON LARGE, COMMERCIAL AIRCRAFT TEST BED (THE BOEING 757 ECODEMONSTRATOR).   2.2	OBJECTIVES FOR THIS TASK ORDER ARE AS FOLLOWS: 	FABRICATE AN AFC SYSTEM IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE AFC SYSTEM DESIGN DEVELOPED UNDER SMAAART TASK ORDER NNL13AC06T 	MODIFY THE 757 BLEED AIR SYSTEM IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE AFC SYSTEM DESIGN DEVELOPED UNDER SMAAART TASK ORDER NNL13AC06T 	INSTALL THE AFC SYSTEM INTO THE BOEING 757 ECODEMONSTRATOR VERTICAL TAIL IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE AFC SYSTEM DESIGN DEVELOPED UNDER SMAAART TASK ORDER NNL13AC06T 	FLIGHT TEST THE AFC SYSTEM INCLUDING BASELINE AND UP TO 2 AFC CONFIGURATIONS. 	FABRICATE AND INSTALL A CAMERA PLATFORM AT WINDOWS 2 AND 3 IN THE 757 ECODEMONSTRATOR 	INSTALLATION DESIGN AND INSTALL OPTICALLY CLEAR WINDOWS 2 AND 3 IN THE 757 ECODEMONSTRATOR 	INSTALLATION DESIGN AND INSTALL CAMERAS AND OTHER CAMERA ASSOCIATED EQUIPMENT 	INSTALLATION DESIGN AND INSTALL THE NASA-PROVIDED ENGINEERED SURFACES ON THE 757 ECODEMONSTRATOR SLATS 8 AND 9 	QUANTIFY IN FLIGHT THE INSECT IMPACT DENSITY ON WING SLATS 8 AND 9 THROUGH OPERATION OF THE CAMERA SYSTEM 	PROVIDE GROUND SUPPORT TO ASSIST NASA IN THE POST-FLIGHT INSECT ACCRETIONS INSPECTIONS 	PROVIDE FLIGHT SERVICES AND AIRCRAFT ACCESS FOR USE BY NASA AND THE CONTRACTOR 	PROVIDE ALL PERSONNEL (INCLUDING QUALIFIED PILOTS), GROUND EQUIPMENT, TOOLS, AND OTHER EQUIPMENT NECESSARY TO CONDUCT THE NASA RESEARCH FLIGHTS AND GROUND SUPPORT 2.3	APPLICABLE DOCUMENTS     DOC. Description of Work: IGF::OT::IGF     TASK ORDER - STATEMENT OF WORK (SOW) TASK TITLE:  DESIGN OF TRANSONIC JUNCTURE FLOW MODEL  1.0	INTRODUCTION/BACKGROUND:  THE GOAL OF THE REVOLUTIONARY COMPUTATIONAL AEROSCIENCES SUB-PROJECT OF THE AERONAUTICAL SCIENCES PROJECT IN FUNDAMENTAL AERONAUTICS PROGRAM IS TO IMPROVE PREDICTIVE CAPABILITY OF TURBULENT SEPARATED FLOWS.  NASA HAS PARTICIPATED WITH OTHER NATIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS IN A SERIES OF WORKSHOPS TO EVALUATE THE STATE OF THE ART IN COMPUTATIONAL FLUID DYNAMICS (CFD) PREDICTIVE CAPABILITY FOR AEROSPACE VEHICLES.  ONE OF THESE WORKSHOPS THAT STARTED IN 1999 IS THE AMERICAN INSTITUTE OF AERONAUTICS AND ASTRONAUTICS (AIAA) DRAG PREDICTION WORKSHOP (DPW) SERIES.  THE ORGANIZING COMMITTEE OF DPW SERIES IDENTIFIED PREDICTION OF TURBULENT SEPARATED JUNCTURE FLOW AS A CRITICAL ISSUE FOR IMPROVING THE PREDICTIVE CAPABILITY OF TRANSONIC AEROSPACE VEHICLES.  FIVE WORKSHOPS OVER MORE THAN A DECADE DEMONSTRATE THAT THE UNCERTAINTY IN SEPARATION PREDICTION IS AFFECTED BY THE GRID TOPOLOGY, GRID DENSITY, AND TURBULENCE MODEL.  HOWEVER, THERE IS INSUFFICIENT EXPERIMENTAL DATA TO DETERMINE WHICH PREDICTIONS OF THE SEPARATION REGION ARE CORRECT AND WHY OTHER PREDICTIONS ARE NOT CORRECT.  MODERN AEROSPACE VEHICLES HAVE MANY JUNCTURE REGIONS.  AIRPLANES HAVE SIMILAR JUNCTURE FLOWS AT THE WING-BODY, HORIZONTAL TAIL-BODY, VERTICAL TAIL-BODY, WING-PYLON, NACELLE-PYLON, AND FLAP TRACK FAIRING-WING JUNCTURES.  NEXT GENERATION CONFIGURATIONS SUCH AS THE TRUSS-BRACED WING HAVE EVEN LARGER JUNCTURE REGIONS.  THE ABILITY TO PREDICT THE ONSET AND PROGRESSION OF SEPARATION FLOW IN THESE JUNCTURE REGIONS IS CRITICAL TO ACCURATE PREDICTION OF FORCES AND MOMENTS AND THEREFORE CRITICAL TO DESIGN OF FUEL EFFICIENT AND QUIET AIRCRAFT.  ADDITIONALLY, SPACE LAUNCH VEHICLES HAVE SIMILAR JUNCTURE REGIONS.  THE DPW ORGANIZING COMMITTEE DISCUSSED THE DEVELOPMENT OF A UNIT TEST PROBLEM TO PROVIDE VALIDATION DATA FOR CFD PREDICTIONS OF THE JUNCTURE FLOW.  THE ORGANIZING COMMITTEE IDENTIFIED A CONFIGURATION WITH A LIGHTLY LOADED, SHORT WING SPAN THAT COULD BE SCALED LARGE ENOUGH TO ALLOW ACCURATE MEASUREMENTS OF THE MEAN AND TURBULENT FLOW IN THE SEPARATION REGION.  THE VALIDATION TEST WOULD UTILIZE A COMMERCIALLY AVAILABLE INTERNALLY MOUNTED LASER DOPPLER VELOCIMETRY (LDV) SYSTEM TO MEASURE THE FLOW NEAR THE FUSELAGE AND WING SURFACES IN THE SEPARATED REGION, STATIC PRESSURE PORTS, AND UNSTEADY PRESSURE MEASUREMENTS.  THE WING WOULD BE DESIGNED TO HAVE A PRESSURE GRADIENT SIMILAR TO NASAS COMMON RESEARCH MODEL (CRM) GEOMETRY, WHICH IS AN OPEN GEOMETRY REPRESENTATIVE OF MODERN IN-SERVICE COMMERCIAL TRANSPORT AIRCRAFT.  FURTHER, THE VALIDATION TEST CONFIGURATION WOULD HAVE TWO PLANES OF SYMMETRY: LEFT-RIGHT AND TOP-BOTTOM ALLOWING MULTIPLE ROTATION ANGLES IN THE EXPERIMENTAL TEST MATRIX TO PROVIDE ESTIMATES OF TUNNEL EFFECTS.  MULTIPLE PLANES OF SYMMETRY ARE POWERFUL TOOLS FOR VALIDATION EXPERIMENTS.  THE VALIDATION TEST WILL BE DESIGNED WITH FOUR FLOW TYPES: 1) ATTACHED FLOW, 2) INCIPIENT SEPARATION, 3) SMALL WING-BODY SEPARATION, AND 4) LARGE SCALE SEPARATION.    BOEING, AS PART OF THE DPW ORGANIZING COMMITTEE, DEVELOPED A DESIGN OF A JUNCTURE FLOW MODEL.  THIS FIRST DESIGN WAS DETERMINED TO BE INSUFFICIENT TO MOUNT THE INTERNAL INSTRUMENTATION, AND BOEING SUBSEQUENTLY PROVIDED AN UPDATED DESIGN TO THE DPW ORGANIZING COMMITTEE.  ANALYSIS OF THIS MODEL AT NASA LANGLEY IDENTIFIED THAT THE MODEL DID NOT PROVIDE THE FOUR FLOW TYPES, THE FUSELAGE WAS TOO NARROW TO ACCOMMODATE THE INTERNAL INSTRUMENTATION AND TRAVERSE SYSTEM, AND THE EXIT AREA OF THE FUSELAGE WAS TOO SMALL TO ACCOMMODATE ALL OF THE INSTRUMENTATION CABLING THAT WAS REQUIRED.  THE WORK DESCRIBED IN THIS TASK ORDER IS REQUIRED TO ESTABLISH AN OPEN, PUBLIC-DOMAIN GEOMETRY FOR THE OUTER MOLD LINE OF THE JUNCTURE FLOW MODEL THAT ADDRESSES THE ISSUES WITH THE PREVIOUS DESIGN.  THE JUNCTURE MODEL SHALL BE DESIGNED WITH A THINNER WING TO USE ANGLE OF ATTACK TO
